analytic.title: Antioxidants, reactive oxygen and nitrogen species, gene induction and mitochondrial function

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Introduction
div.p: There has been increasing interest, in recent years, in the possibility that reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS) act as signals, or mediators of changes, in cell function, proliferation and differentiation in addition to more traditionally acknowledged roles in cell damage and death. This clearly has implications for understanding the roles and requirements for the antioxidant nutrients, since by inference they would also be expected to play a modulating role in these essential cellular processes. Understanding the relative importance of these disparate roles of oxidants and nutrients is therefore seen as crucial to evaluation of the role of antioxidants in the modulation of chronic disease processes, ageing and cell death.

A better understanding of the requirements for antioxidants would be gained if it were possible to understand the processes by which, ROS/RNS act as modulators of cellular function or result in cellular damage. An intimate link is becoming apparent between cellular oxidants, antioxidants, cellular redox and the control of signalling pathways and gene expression (Sen and Packer, 1996). The cellular redox state is increasingly recognised as a crucial mediator and influence on multiple metabolic, signalling and transcriptional processes in cells essential for their normal functioning and survival.

At the current stage of development of this novel area relatively few studies have examined the effect of antioxidant nutrients at levels likely to be relevant to nutritional studies in vivo. The approach has been to use antioxidant nutrients and/or pharmacological agents with antioxidant properties at high concentrations where effects are apparent in traditional cell or molecular biological experiments. Much of the data presented must, therefore, be considered descriptive of processes that can occur under certain circumstances in vitro rather than proven actions in the body. Nevertheless, the potential importance of this field is large. By implication the diverse group of dietary compounds known as antioxidants may have the capacity to regulate multiple key cellular processes such as cell proliferation and apoptosis with important implications for understanding major disorders such as coronary heart diseases and cancer and their prevention.

The review that follows will describe examples of the processes and pathways currently known to be influenced by ROS and RNS and/or antioxidants. A specific section of the review will deal with the major role played by oxidants in mitochondria and by mitochondria on oxidant generation. Finally, since this rapidly developing field is likely to be influenced by developments in novel technologies, which allow rapid evaluation of diverse effects of oxidants on gene and protein expression, the review will include a brief description of these technologies and where they are likely to play a role in future developments.

div.head: Redox-sensitive cell signalling
div.p: Under conditions of oxidative stress, cellular responses to ROS are critical in helping to maintain cellular functions, and in making the decision between cell survival and death. However, an ever-increasing body of experimental evidence suggests that the balance of oxidants, antioxidants, and redox status, within cells, is important in the regulation of gene expression, even in the absence of overt stress. Indeed, changes in cellular redox may be integrally associated with cell differentiation and cycling and ageing processes (Adler et al., 1999b;Chen et al., 1995). In some instances, ROS may act as bona fide second messengers (Suzuki et al., 1997). Antioxidants, be they cellular, dietary, or pharmacological in origin, will influence intracellular ROS levels and, in so doing, may modulate their influence on patterns of gene expression.

ROS may arise from both extracellular and intracellular sources. Extracellular ROS can initiate cellular signalling by activation of growth factor and cytokine re-ceptors in a manner that does not require the presence of the receptor ligands (Coffer et al., 1995;Hayes and Lockwood, 1987;Huang et al., 1996;Kadota et al., 1987;Koshio et al., 1988;Miller et al., 1994;Rao, 1996;Rosette and Karin, 1996;Sachsenmaier et al., 1994) or via generation of lipid peroxides within cell membranes (Suzuki et al., 1997).

A variety of stimuli lead to intracellular ROS production. Tumour necrosis factora (TNF-a) provokes a rise in hydrogen peroxide production from mitochondria, and other ROS, via induction of NADPH oxidase (Garcia-Ruiz et al., 1997;Lo and Cruz, 1995). Interaction of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and epidermal growth factor (EGF) with their receptors causes a transient increase in hydrogen peroxide. In the case of PDGF, this increase in hydrogen peroxide has been shown to be essential for growth induction.

Well over 100 mammalian genes have been identified that can be regulated by cellular redox state (Adler et al., 1999b;Allen and Tresini, 2000;Morel and Barouki, 1999). Much of the redox-sensitive regulation of gene expression is transcriptional although alterations in mRNA stability (Chen et al., 1998;De Kimpe et al., 1998;Esposito et al., 1997;Ming et al., 1998;Shen et al., 1995) or protein stability (Adler et al., 1999a;Iwai et al., 1998;Shen et al., 1995) can be important.

In many respects, the effects of RNS parallel the effects of ROS and antioxidants on cellular functions. It is widely recognised that nitric oxide (NO Å ), biosynthesised from L-arginine, has beneficial physiological effects such as enhancing vasodilatation and inhibiting formation of platelet thrombi and, therefore, is protective against cardiovascular disease (Li and Forstermann, 2000). Indeed a common variant of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS Glu 298 ! Asp) is an important risk factor for coronary artery disease (Hingorani et al., 1999). Low levels of NO Å are produced constantly by the endothelium without the requirement for agonists such as acetylcholine, and this is achieved by normal shear stress induced by blood flow. The product of the Akt proto-oncogene (protein kinase B), a serine/threonine kinase, can directly phosphorylate eNOS (Fulton et al., 1999). There is evidence that dietary antioxidants may enhance the formation of NO Å (Tomasian et al., 2000).

NO Å neutralises lipid peroxides to form nitrolipids (ROONO), thus demonstrating chain-breaking activity and it can be considered as an antioxidant. However, NO Å also regulates gene expression, and has potent anti-proliferative effects and generally has pro-apoptotic activity. Chronic inhibition of endothelial NO Å synthesis induces vascular inflammatory changes, including monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 expression and medial thickening, but not fibrosis (Kitamoto et al., 2000). NO Å also maintains smooth muscle cells in their contractile phenotype (Bundy et al., 2000). Indeed gene therapy with different NOS isoforms is being investigated as a protective measure during transplant procedures, especially those involving blood vessels (Channon et al., 2000).

As a strong oxidant, peroxynitrite may influence gene expression, as well as signalling mechanisms such as the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI-3K/Akt) pathway (Klotz et al., 2000), by the induction of specific nuclear transcription factors (Patel et al., 2000). Information in this area is limited and contradictory. NO Å may inhibit tissue factor expression by the prior formation of peroxynitrite (Gerlach et al., 1998).

However, peroxynitrite appears to mediate increases in the expression of interleukin (IL)-8 by lipopolysaccharide, which is normally inhibited by NO Å (Filep et al., 1998). NO Å inhibits aromatase expression in granulosa cells, whereas peroxynitrite does not (Kagabu et al., 1999). Similarly, in liver hepatic reperfusion injury, peroxynitrite decreases the expression of P-selectin and intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) (Liu et al., 2000) suggesting a protective role. In other systems where NO Å has no effect, peroxynitrite, produced by exposure to TNFa and IL-1b, lowered the expression of osteocalcin and inhibits osteoblastic differentiation (Hikiji et al., 2000). Of particular importance is the observation that peroxynitrite induced the expression of manganese superoxide dismutate (MnSOD) in lung epithelial cells, but not the total amount of enzyme protein (Jackson et al., 1998). It may also upregulate haem oxygenase-1 and haem-binding protein 23 in Kuppfer's cells (Immenschuh et al., 1999). Therefore, the effects of this oxidant may be gene-dependent, and possibly tissue-dependent, although the evidence for this is not clear. Relatively little has been done to establish which transcription factors are involved in these responses to peroxynitrite. It is possible that addition of exogenous peroxynitrite may give rise to nitration, and therefore modification of transcription factors. However, there is evidence that the transcription factor AP-1 may be more important (Gertzberg et al., 2000) for peroxynitrite than NF-jB, which is assumed to be the principal mechanism for oxidant stress.

Alterations in cellular redox and nitrosative conditions modulate the activity of many transcription factors (Allen and Tresini, 2000;Belsham and Mellon, 2000;Berendji et al., 1999;Chiu et al., 1999;Deora et al., 2000;Huang et al., 1999). The activity of these can be influenced by various upstream signalling cascades as well as by direct oxidation/reduction reactions. The pathways involved have not been mapped definitively. In many cases, pathways overlap and a multitude of stimuli can act within each pathway, at different levels. This complexity provides the scope for the exquisite cellular flexibility to respond in different ways, often in a tissue-specific manner, to alterations in environment. At the same time, it makes unravelling the mechanisms involved complex and explains the often confusing, and sometimes apparently contradictory, results from studies to date.

Within this review, the most extensively characterised components associated with redox-sensitive cell signalling will be described and recurrent themes in redox regulation of cell function discussed. More in-depth analyses of some of the individual topics raised here are available in several recent reviews (Adler et al., 1999b;Allen and Tresini, 2000;Chakraborti and Chakraborti, 1998;Ginn-Pease and Whisler, 1998;Gius et al., 1999;Kamata and Hirata, 1999;Li and Karin, 1999;Marshall et al., 2000;Morel and Barouki, 1999;Powis et al., 2000).

div.head: Thiol groups and the regulation of gene expression
div.p: Thiol groups are central to most, if not all, redox-sensitive cell signalling mechanisms. Oxidation of thiol groups is a reversible process that represents a sensitive redox-regulated functional switch. Specifically, oxidation/reduction of cysteine thiol groups, within key proteins, controls the dynamics of redox-sensitive gene expression.

The thiol-containing compound glutathione (GSH) acts as the primary cellular homeostatic 'redox buffer'. It is present in cells at concentrations varying from 5 to 10 mmol/l (Morel and Barouki, 1999). Under normal conditions, approximately 1% of the total cellular glutathione is in the oxidised form (GSSG) (Dalton et al., 1999). Thus, oxidation of only a small proportion of the GSH in a cell can shift significantly the GSH:GSSG ratio, with consequent implications for patterns of gene expression (Hwang et al., 1992;Ishii et al., 1987). ROS provoke the formation of intra-or intermolecular disulphide bridges between cysteines. This process may cause conformational changes or generate dimers or multimers that have the potential to alter protein function (Adler et al., 1999b).

Thioredoxins are ubiquitous thiol-reactive proteins. Mammalian thioredoxins include thioredoxin-1 (Trx1), mitochondrial Trx2, and a thioredoxin-like protein p32 TrxL (Powis et al., 2000). They act to reduce oxidised cysteine residues in proteins. Cysteine residues present in a conserved -trp-cys-cys-gly-pro-cys-lys-redox catalytic site, within all thioredoxins, become oxidised during this process. Thioredoxin reductases, acting in concert with NADPH, recycle the thioredoxins by returning these cysteine residues to their reduced form.

Trx1 is predominantly located in the cytosol, but agents such as phorbol esters, UV irradiation and hydrogen peroxide promote its translocation to the nucleus (Powis et al., 2000). The mechanism that drives this is unknown, but it may be that the Trx1 is bound to another protein, possibly NF-jB (see below), which is targeted to the nucleus under such conditions.

In addition to their role in reducing and refolding oxidised protein, thioredoxins have the capacity to act at several levels in respect of redox-regulated gene expression. The fact that they can reduce hydrogen peroxide and act as electron donors for glutathione peroxidase suggests that they may have direct antioxidant functions (Bjornstedt et al., 1994;Spector et al., 1988). Equally, Trx1 appears to regulate the activity of transcription factors within the nucleus by altering their thiol redox state and consequent DNA-binding affinity. Available evidence suggests that this could be a significant factor in determining activity for several transcription factors including NF-jB, AP-1, glucocorticoid receptor and p53 (Makino et al., 1999;Matthews et al., 1992;Okamoto et al., 1999;Tanaka et al., 1999). In some cases, Trx1 appears to interact directly with the transcription factors. In others, it may act via the redoxsensitive protein Ref-1, a key nuclear regulator of transcription factor redox state (Abate et al., 1990;Adler et al., 1999b).

Finally, thioredoxins can also interact with, and modulate the function of, protein kinases such as signal-related kinase ASK1 (a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase) (Saitoh et al., 1998). Such protein kinases are central to many cellsignalling pathways.

div.head: Redox-sensitive signal transduction pathways
div.p: ROS can act through several different pathways of signal transduction, making use of signalling molecules such as calcium, protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs) and protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs), serine/threonine kinases, and phospholipases.

div.head: Protein kinases
div.p: Phosphorylation cascades are involved in many mechanisms for the transmission of extracellular signals from the plasma membrane to the cell nucleus. Numerous studies have found that oxidant treatment of cells produces elevations in protein phosphorylation and various protein kinase activities (Abe et al., 1997;Bauskin et al., 1991;Devary et al., 1992;Hardwick and Sefton, 1995;Hardwick and Sefton, 1997;Kurata, 2000;Nakamura et al., 1993;Ruff et al., 1997;Schieven et al., 1993;Secrist et al., 1993;Yurchak et al., 1996).

The mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinases are one of the most extensively studied families of protein kinases (Kolch, 2000). Several MAP kinase-related pathways have been identified (ERK, JNK/SAPK, p38 kinase, and BMK/ERK5). These kinase families exist in all eukaryotes, and control essential processes such as proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis.

In each case, the cascades function according to a common theme ( Fig. 1). Upstream signals feed into a three-tier cascade of core kinases. In the case of the ERK pathway, the signal upstream of these kinases is co-ordinated by the G protein Ras. Ras regulates the activity of a MAP kinase kinase kinase (termed variously MAP-KKK, MAP3K or MEKK) that activates a MAP kinase kinase (MAPKK, MAP2K, MKK, or MEK), which in turn activates a MAP kinase (MAPK). This format provides a means of signal amplification and the potential for multiple levels of regulation.

Many studies of kinase substrate specificity in vitro suggest that cross-talk can occur at different levels in the pathways. However, great caution must be used in extrapolating from such studies since they can reveal spurious interactions that have no physiological significance.

Components of each of the MAP kinases, or related pathway, contain redoxsensitive sites that provide the potential for modulation of the signalling via cellular redox status. ROS can activate MAP kinases via a Ras-dependent mechanism (Aikawa et al., 1997;Fialkow et al., 1994;Guyton et al., 1996;Qin et al., 1997;Rao, 1996). For example, oxidative stress has been shown to activate Ras (Lander et al., 1995). Evidence that NO Å reacts with cysteine 118, on the surface of Ras, to activate the G protein suggests that this residue may represent a redox-sensitive switch (Lander et al., 1995;Lander et al., 1996;Lander et al., 1997). Additionally, there is evidence that oxidants stimulate assembly of the multiprotein complex (SHC-Grb2-Sos) that converts inactive Ras-GDP to active Ras-GTP (Rao, 1996).

Once activated, Ras stimulates the small G protein Rac that, in turn, activates membrane bound NADPH oxidase to produce ROS. These ROS are required to mediate mitogenic stimulation. Thus, redox regulation may modulate these protein phosphorylation cascades at multiple levels and further examples of this are described in the following sections.

Another important kinase signalling pathway involves protein kinase C (PKC). PKC is not a single enzyme. Rather, cellular PKC activity arises from a family of at least 12 related enzymes. Activation of PKC by diacylglycerol and by phorbol esters is well established. The mechanisms of activation involve lipids, calcium, and PKC phosphorylation ( Fig. 2) (Newton, 1997).

ROS have been demonstrated to activate members of the PKC family (Newton, 1995;Nishizuka, 1995). Treatment of cells with hydrogen peroxide stimulates PKC activity (Brawn et al., 1995;Larsson and Cerutti, 1989;Whisler et al., 1995). Hydrogen peroxide can induce tyrosine phosphorylation of PKC, enhancing its activity (Konishi et al., 1997). PKCs also contain structural motifs that are susceptible to redox modification. Selective oxidation within the amino-terminal domain, which contains a zinc-thiolate structure, can activate PKC (Gopalakrishna and Anderson, 1989). On the other hand, oxidative modification within the carboxy terminal domain inactivates PKC (Gopalakrishna and Anderson, 1987). This may explain why PKC appears to be subject to dual redox regulation with lower levels of ROS Fig. 1. Schematic representation of the ERK (blue), JNK (pink), and p38 (green) MAP kinase pathways. Interaction of growth factor receptor tyrosine kinases with ligands or oxidants stimulates their dimerisation and autophosphorylation (A). This promotes formation of the Grb2-S0S-Ras complex and conversion of Ras to its active form by exchange of GTP for GDP (B). GTP-Ras activates MAP kinase kinase kinases (MAP3Ks) for the ERK and JNK pathways. The MAP3Ks phosphorylate and activate the corresponding MAP2Ks and these phosphorylate the MAPKs. Active ERK enhances NK-kB and AP-1 activity by phosphorylating the p65 and c-Fos subunits of these transcription factors. ERK may also play a role in promoting the dissociation of Nrf2 from the cytoskeleton-associated protein Keap1, permitting its translocation to the nucleus and activation of the ARE. Similarly, active JNK phosphorylates the c-Jun subunit of AP-1. The JNK and p38 pathways may also be activated via cytokine receptors and the small G proteins Rac and Cdc42. For the p38 pathway, p21 (Ras) activated kinase (PAK) may operate upstream of the MAP3K (MEKK3). Identified targets for the p38 kinase include the transcription factor GADD153. Oxidative stress is a potent activator of the protein phosphates CL100, which can inactivate ERK. This may act as a feedback control loop for the oxidant-induced activation of the ERK pathway. stimulating its activity but higher levels inhibiting it (Gopalakrishna and Anderson, 1991). In addition, oxidised diacylglycerol stimulates PKC (O'Brian et al., 1988;Takekoshi et al., 1995). This represents another example in which ROS can regulate cell-signalling pathways by a number of distinct processes.

div.head: Protein phosphatases
div.p: Protein phosphorylation is balanced by the action of protein kinases and phosphatases. Both serine/threonine phosphatases and PTPs are known to be redoxsensitive (Nemani and Lee, 1993;Wang et al., 1996). The mechanism is best understood for the PTPs where the catalytic domain contains a conserved motif with a single cysteine residue. Mutation or oxidation of this cysteine renders the enzymes inactive. Furthermore, hydrogen peroxide has been demonstrated to be a potent inhibitor of PTPs (Lee et al., 1998). Inhibition of PTPs may be responsible for the Oxidants can induce the formation of lipid peroxides in cell membranes and activate phospholipase Cc (PLCc), protein tyrosine kinases (PTKs) and MAP kinase cascades (MAPKs). Lipid peroxides provoke structural changes and membrane disruption leading to increased influx of calcium ions. PLCc releases diacyl glycerol (DAG) and inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP3) from phosphatidyl inositol. IP3 promotes release of calcium ions from stores in the endoplasmic reticulum. DAG and increased cytosolic calcium concentrations activate protein kinase C and promote its translocation to the plasma membrane. PCK activity may also be modulated by redox conditions and by the action of protein tyrosine kinases. Phospholipase A2 (PLA2) is also activated and translocated to the plasma membrane in response to increased cytosolic calcium concentrations and possibly by phosphorylation by PKC or MAPKs. The products of PLA2 activity are arachidonic acid (AA) and its metabolites, which are primary mediators of immune and inflammatory responses. Oxidants may also stimulate phospholipase D activity, probably via the action of PTKs. activation of some PTKs following oxidant treatment (Fantus et al., 1989;Heffetz et al., 1992;Knebel et al., 1996;Secrist et al., 1993).

On the other hand, oxidative stress is a potent inducer of expression of the protein phosphatase CL100 (Keyse and Emslie, 1992). This enzyme is capable of dephosphorylating ERK and most likely represents a negative feedback loop for ROSinduced activation of ERK ( Fig. 1).

div.head: Lipids and phospholipases
div.p: Oxidants have been shown to activate several classes of phospholipases, (Fig. 2). Activation of phospholipase Cc leads to the release of DG and inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP3). DG activates PKC, as noted above, while IP3 provokes release of calcium into the cytosol from intracellular pools (Berridge, 1993). Oxidants, such as hydrogen peroxide and vanadate, have been shown to lead to PLCc phosphorylation and concomitant increases in IP3 (Bianchini et al., 1993;Blake et al., 1993;Schieven et al., 1993).

Oxidants can also activate phospholipases A and D (Chakraborti and Chakraborti, 1995;Chakraborti and Michael, 1993;Goldman et al., 1992;Ito et al., 1997;Kim et al., 1997;Kiss and Anderson, 1994;Natarajan et al., 1993;Natarajan et al., 1996;Tournier et al., 1997). The underlying mechanisms of activation are not known. However, lipid peroxidation within cell membranes, PKC, PLCc, calcium and/or Rac, may be involved in PLA 2 activation (Chakraborti and Chakraborti, 1995;Chakraborti and Michael, 1993;Nishizuka, 1992;Suzuki et al., 1997) while PTKs and calcium may participate in oxidant-induced activation of PLD (Ito et al., 1997;Natarajan et al., 1996).

Arachidonic acid, the predominant reaction product of PLA 2 action, and its metabolites are mediators of processes such as inflammation and immune response. They also appear to be critical to ERK and JNK activation as inhibitors of PLA 2 and arachidonic acid metabolism can block oxidant-induced stimulation of these kinases (Tournier et al., 1997).

div.head: Antioxidant (electrophile) response element
div.p: Oxidative stress induces the co-ordinated expression of a number of genes including several encodings for phase II detoxifying enzymes. The promoter regions of many such genes contain a cis-acting sequence, termed the antioxidant (or electrophile) response element (ARE/EpRE) (Favreau and Pickett, 1991;Friling et al., 1990;Li and Jaiswal, 1992;. Examples of genes regulated by ARE/EpRE are NADPH-quinone oxidoreductase (Favreau and Pickett, 1991), glutathione-S-transferase , UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (Prestera et al., 1995), thioredoxin (Kim et al., 2001), haem oxygenase-1 (Inamdar et al., 1996) and ferritin (Tsuji et al., 2000). The ARE/EpRE is important for the inducible expression of these genes. Evidence points towards the erythroid transcription factor (NF-E2)-related transcription factors as the ones that bind to the promoter of these genes. These transcription factors, Nrf1 and Nrf2, heterodimerise with small Maf proteins and bind to ARE/EpRE elements. In particular, Nrf2 seems to be important for regulation of ARE/EpRE-mediated gene transcription (Alam et al., 1999;Hayes et al., 2000;Itoh et al., 1997;Wild et al., 1999). Nguyen et al. (2000) have obtained results suggesting that small Maf proteins repress transcription through ARE/EpRE whereas Nrf2 transactivates through these sequences. Also, Nrf1 has been shown to regulate the gene encoding the phase II enzyme gamma-glutamylcysteine synthetase (Myhrstad et al., 2001). Regulation of Nrf2 activity may also be achieved by retention of the protein in the cytoplasm by interaction with the cytoskeleton-associated protein Keap1 (Itoh et al., 1999). Release of Nrf2 from Keap1 permits its translocation to the nucleus. Thus, the Nrf2-Keap1 interaction may act as a cytoplasmic sensor for oxidative stress (Itoh et al., 1999) although the mechanisms regulating this interaction have not been elucidated.

The importance of Nrf2 for combating oxidative stress is clearly demonstrated in studies of mice where the gene encoding Nrf2 has been knocked out. These mice are rapidly depleted of hepatic glutathione when challenged with inducers of oxidative stress (Chan et al., 2001).

Extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 and p38 have been shown to influence ARE-mediated transcription in a positive and negative manner, respectively (Yu et al., 1999(Yu et al., , 2000. Other evidence suggests that PKC may be important in Nrf2 activation. ARE-directed transcription can be activated by the PKC activator phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, and blocked by the PCK inhibitors (Huang et al., 2000). PKC can phosphorylate Nrf2 in vitro and probably in vivo (Huang et al., 2000). This may provide the mechanisms for disassociation and nuclear translocation of the transcription factor. In addition, both Keap1 and the small MAF proteins have putative target sites for phosphorylation by PKC (Itoh et al., 1997).

div.head: Intracellular calcium signalling
div.p: Intracellular calcium concentrations modulate many cellular processes including gene transcription. Oxidants stimulate an increase in intracellular free calcium concentration in most models (Bianchini et al., 1993;Kamata and Hirata, 1999;Qin et al., 1996;Schieven et al., 1993). Studies using different model systems suggest that the source of the calcium can be intracellular, extracellular, or a combination of the two (Qin et al., 1996;Qin et al., 1997;Suzuki et al., 1997). Oxidant-induced IP3 release represents one component of the signal transduction pathway for calcium release (Fig. 2). Furthermore, IP3-receptor activity is regulated by cellular thiol status (Kaplin et al., 1994;Missiaen et al., 1991;Renard et al., 1992).

div.head: Transcription factors
div.p: Numerous transcription factors exhibit redox sensitivity. Three of the most extensively characterised examples, NF-jB, AP-1 and p53, are discussed here. For details of other transcription factors see Table 1.

div.head: NF-jB
div.p: NF-jB has, for some time, been held as the paradigm model of a redox-sensitive transcription factor (Li and Karin, 1999;Schreck et al., 1992). A substantial body of Abate et al. (1991), Angel and Karin (1991), Ares et al. (1995), Hill and Treisman (1995), Manna et al. (1998), Meyer et al. (1993), Muller et al. (1997), Munoz et al. Regulation of a wide range of genes Regulation of DNA binding and possible interaction with NF-jB Ammendola et al. (1994), Knoepfel et al. (1994), Rippe et al. (1999), Wu et al. (1996) experimental data links NF-jB activity to cellular oxidative status. As such, the NF-jB system (Fig. 3) provides an excellent model for introducing many of the concepts and themes in current scientific thinking on the redox regulation of transcription factors. NF-jB regulates the transcription of a host of genes including acute phase genes, cytokines and cell surface receptors (Baeuerle and Baltimore, 1996;Baeuerle and Henkel, 1994;Baichwal and Baeuerle, 1997;Barnes and Karin, 1997). Hydrogen peroxide treatment of many cell types activates NF-jB (Manna et al., 1998;Meyer et al., 1993;Schreck et al., 1991;Sen and Packer, 1996;Wang et al., 1998), and in some systems antioxidants have been demonstrated to reduce or block NF-jB activation (Manna et al., 1998;Meyer et al., 1993;Schreck et al., 1991). However, hydrogen peroxide does not stimulate NF-jB activation in all cells suggesting that it is not a general mediator of NF-jB activation process (Anderson et al., 1994).

Various other stimuli, such as phorbol esters, pro-inflammatory cytokines and bacterial endotoxin, also activate NF-jB (Li and Karin, 1999). It has been suggested that intracellular ROS levels may be involved in the stimulatory mechanism since Fig. 3. Proposed mechanisms of redox regulation of NF-jB activity. Under basal conditions NK-jB (consisting of the p50 and p65 subunits) is retained in the cytoplasm by interaction with the inhibitor IjB. Oxidants stimulate IjB phosphorylation via the IjB kinases (IKK1 and 2) in the IKK signalsome complex. IKK1 and 2 activation appear to be achieved via MAPK cascades. Phosphorylation of IjB triggers its ubiquitination (U) and degradation. Removal of the IjB unmasks the nuclear targeting signal on NF-jB. This stimulates its translocation to the nucleus. NF-jB DNA binding and transcriptional activation properties within the nucleus may be further modulated by phosphorylation and interaction with thioredoxin 1 (Trx1). Nitric oxide acts to inhibit IjB phosphorylation and degradation. treatment with these agents increases intracellular ROS levels (Schreck et al., 1992). Here again, in many cases, antioxidants can block NF-jB activation by these agents (Beg et al., 1993;Devary et al., 1993;Henkel et al., 1993;Kaltschmidt et al., 1997;Kretz-Remy et al., 1996;Manna et al., 1998;Suzuki et al., 1994;Traenckner et al., 1994). However, the precise role of ROS in the activation mechanism remains to be elucidated (Li and Karin, 1999;Schreck and Baeuerle, 1994;Sen and Packer, 1996). Indeed, even now, one review has called into question the link between NF-jB and redox status (Bowie and O'Neill, 2000), and conclusive proof that redox signalling plays a central role in the regulation of NF-jB activity is still required.

The classical, and predominant, form of NK-jB is a heterodimer consisting of the p65 (RelA) and p50 (NF-jB 1) subunits. However, multiple NF-jB variant forms may exist as hetero-or homodimers of the five known members of the Rel protein family (p65/RelA, c-Rel, RelB, p50/NF-jB 1, and p52/NF-jB 2) (Baldwin, 1996;Verma et al., 1995). The significance of these other less common forms is uncertain. It has been suggested that they may respond to stimuli in different ways, and interact with NF-jB-binding sites with varying affinities, thereby regulating the transcription of discrete subsets of genes (Ginn-Pease and Whisler, 1998).

In most cells under basal conditions, NF-jB is inactive, sequestered in the cytoplasm and bound to the inhibitor IjB. In general, NF-jB activation is initiated by the phosphorylation of IjB on two serine residues (ser 32 and 36). However, redox regulation of NF-jB activity in some cell types may be modulated, via a distinct process involving phosphorylation of tyrosine residues and serines/heronines within the C-terminal PEST (proline-glutamic acid-serine-threonine) domain (Imbert et al., 1996;Schoonbroodt and Piette, 2000).

Phosphorylation acts as the trigger for IjB ubiquitination and degradation although, in certain cell types, UV-C exposure elicits IjB degradation without IjB phosphorylation (Bender et al., 1998;Li and Karin, 1998) and tyrosine phosphorylation of IjB can promote its dissociation from NF-jB without degradation (Imbert et al., 1996). Either way, the removal of IjB unmasks a nuclear targeting domain on NF-jB promoting its translocation to the nucleus.

The kinases responsible for IjB phosphorylation of ser 32 and 36 (IKK1 and IKK2) are present in a multi-protein complex that has been termed the IKK signalsome (DiDonato et al., 1997;Mercurio et al., 1997). There is strong evidence that the activities of the IKKs are regulated by phosphorylation of members of the MAPKKK family. Two candidate kinases, NF-jB-inducing kinase (NIK) and MEKK-1, have been identified. Their relative roles have not been defined, although there is evidence that NIK displays a preference for IKK1 while MEKK-1 reacts preferentially with IKK2 (Nakano et al., 1998). NIK and MEKK-1 are activated by different stimuli thus providing a mechanism for differential and synergistic activation of NF-jB.

Both IKK1 and IKK2 contain cysteine residues in their kinase domains that are critical to their function. It has been hypothesised that phosphorylation of these enzymes could result in structural changes that expose one or more of these cysteine residues and enables them to act as redox-sensitive switches (Gius et al., 1999). This hypothesis remains to be tested.

Although oxidising conditions in the cytoplasm favour translocation of NF-jB to the nucleus, reducing conditions are required within the nucleus for NF-jB DNA binding. This is where Trx1 and Ref-1 have a role to play (Mitomo et al., 1994;Powis et al., 2000). There is evidence suggesting that Trx1 is translocated to the nucleus concomitantly with NF-jB (Hirota et al., 1999). Experiments, both in vitro and in vivo, have demonstrated that Trx1 reduces cysteine 62 in the DNA-binding loop of p50 subunit, and that this promotes DNA binding and transcriptional activation by NF-jB Matthews (Matthews et al., 1992;Okamoto et al., 1992).

Cellular redox status may further modulate NF-jB activity via still another mechanism. Oxidative stress that activates Ras initiates the MAPK cascade (as discussed above). This, in turn, leads to the phosphorylation of the p65 subunit of NF-jB and augments NF-jB-dependent gene transcription.

In contrast to the proposed actions of oxidants on NF-jB, NO Å appears to be able to act at multiple levels to inhibit the activation of NFjB. This may be achieved by reducing IjB phosphorylation, and ubiquitation, which facilitates the degradation of IjB (Fig. 3) (Colasanti and Persichini, 2000).

div.head: AP-1
div.p: The transcription factor AP-1 regulates the expression of genes associated with growth, differentiation, neuronal excitation, and stress. This factor is composed of either homo-or heterodimers of members of the Fos (c-Fos, FosB, Fra1 and Fra2) and Jun (c-Jun, c-JunB, and c-JunD) families (Angel and Karin, 1991). Expression of the different members of these families varies throughout the cell cycle (Franza et al., 1988;Gius et al., 1999). Since the different components possess distinct transcriptional properties, variations in AP-1 composition are likely to modulate its regulatory functions (Gius et al., 1999).

The classical form of AP-1 consists of c-Fos/c-Jun dimers. Regulation of AP-1 activity is known to be through at least two processes: transcriptional regulation of the genes for c-Fos and c-Jun, and phosphorylation of nuclear c-Fos and c-Jun proteins ( Fig. 4) (Xanthoudakis and Curran, 1996). In many cell types, c-Jun and c-Fos expression is induced rapidly and transiently by a variety of stimuli including alterations in cellular redox state (Abate et al., 1990;Angel and Karin, 1991). Phosphorylation of the AP-1 subunits influences its DNA binding and transcriptional regulatory properties. c-Fos appears to be a target for phosphorylation by a component of the Raf-1/ERK pathway (Hill and Treisman, 1995), whereas c-Jun is phosphorylated by c-Jun N terminal kinase (JNK/SAPK) (Treisman, 1995;Woodgett et al., 1994). There is evidence that under basal conditions, JNK is associated with glutathione-S-transferase p, and that this association inhibits JNK regardless of its phosphorylation state (Adler et al., 1999a). Oxidative insult promotes dissociation of this complex and it seems likely that this is an important component in the redox regulation of stress kinase activity.

Some studies have suggested that oxidative stress activates AP-1 (Ares et al., 1995;Sakai et al., 2001). In other experiments, antioxidants and antioxidant enzymes have also been shown to stimulate AP-1 (Manna et al., 1998;Meyer et al., 1993;Munoz et al., 1996;Pahl and Baeuerle, 1994;Schenk et al., 1994;Xia et al., 1996). The reasons for these contradictory results are not clear. It may be that in some instances the antioxidants used actually act as pro-oxidants. An alternative explanation could be that, like NF-jB, extracellular and cytoplasmic pro-oxidant conditions tend to promote AP-1 activation, but reducing conditions within the nucleus are required for DNA binding. Certainly, there is experimental evidence to support the latter part of this theory.

The DNA-binding characteristics of AP-1 can be modulated by the redox status of specific cysteine residues present in both c-Fos and c-Jun. Oxidation of these residues reversibly inactivates the transcription factor (Abate et al., 1990). High levels of thioredoxin are associated with increased AP-1 activity (Freemerman et al., 1999). In this instance, however, it does not seem to be Trx1 that acts upon AP-1 directly. Instead Trx1 has been shown to enhance AP-1 DNA binding in a process requiring Ref-1 (Hirota et al., 1997;. The interaction between Trx1 and Ref-1 is dependent on the presence of the cysteine residues in the Trx1 catalytic site (Hirota et al., 1997). Purified Ref-1 protein stimulates AP-1 DNA-binding activity through the same cysteine residues (Cys-154 on c-Fos and cys-272 on c-Jun) shown to be sensitive to chemical oxidation-reduction in vitro . This suggests that these critical residues are targets for redox driven cell signalling.

Furthermore, it has also been shown that transcription of the gene for Fra-1, a member of the AP-1 family of transcription factors and repressor of AP-1 activity, can be induced by phenolic antioxidants (Yoshioka et al., 1995). This suggests that antioxidants have a dual function in AP-1 activity regulation, and open up the possibility that antioxidants are important in a regulatory feedback mechanism for AP-1 activity. Transactivation of Fra-1 may be mediated by a consensus ARE sequences found in the 5 0 promoter of the Fra-1 gene (Tsuchiya et al., 1993). Further interactions may exist as Fra-1 has been found to repress transcription of NAD(P)H:oxidoreductase 1 (Venugopal and Jaiswal, 1996).

Although the processes underlying NF-jB and AP-1 regulation share many common themes, they do differ in at least one significant respect. NF-jB is able to carry signals from the cytoplasm to the nucleus, when it is translocated. In contrast, c-Fos and c-Jun are largely, if not exclusively, confined to the nucleus. In this case, MAP kinases appear to pass the signal between the different cell compartments (Karin and Smeal, 1992).

div.head: p53
div.p: The p53 tumour suppressor gene encodes a transcription factor that has been termed the 'guardian of the genome'. Cellular stress can lead to p53 activation, which triggers transcription of p53-dependent genes. These genes play a central role in the regulation of cell cycle arrest and apoptosis.

Expression of p53, at the level of the protein, can be stimulated under conditions of oxidative stress (O'Reilly et al., 1998), as can its DNA-binding properties (Tishler et al., 1993). However, it is far from clear that oxidative conditions always promote p53 activity.

In some instances p53 activation by oxidative stress may result from ROS-induced DNA damage production. Detection of such damage promotes p53 protein phosphorylation in a process that appears to be regulated by DNA-dependent protein kinase (Woo et al., 1998). Also, cellular detection of DNA damage may reduce the rate of p53 degradation in a process regulated though its interaction with the MDM2 protein (Haupt et al., 1997;Kubbutat et al., 1997;Lane, 1998).

In addition to the regulation through processes related to DNA damage, p53 activity may also be modulated directly by redox conditions. Oxidation of p53 impairs its DNA-binding capacity (Parks et al., 1997) via a cysteine-dependent mechanism. In fact, multiple cysteine residues within p53 are involved in the redox regulation of its activity (Rainwater et al., 1995). The redox regulator Ref-1 can reactivate DNA binding of oxidised p53 (Jayaraman et al., 1997) and, as for AP-1, may play an important role in p53 activation following cellular oxidative challenge. Also, it is interesting to note that others have found that zinc is required in combination with thiol-reducing agents to reactivate p53 DNA-binding activity follow-ing oxidative inhibition. This suggests that at least some of the cysteine residues are involved in zinc binding and that this is critical for function.

div.head: Cellular responses to oxidative stress
div.p: Cells may respond to changes in environmental exposure to oxidative stress and to endogenous free radical production by increasing or decreasing cell proliferation, changing immune response or by induction of apoptotic cell death. All of these processes involve ATP-dependent signalling pathways, and can only occur within the context of a viable cell. All appear to be regulated by closely integrated signalling pathways (Lind et al., 1999). In contrast, extreme levels of oxidative stress may give rise to necrotic cell death, a pathological process, which is considered to be a passive process (Darzynkiewicz et al., 1997;Samali et al., 1999). In many cases, however, there is no clear-cut delineation between apoptosis and necrosis; for example, adherent cells in culture that lose contact with other cells or the substratum may initially become apoptotic but then progress into a state more akin to necrosis (Przybyszewski et al., 1998;Rytomaa et al., 1999) (see Section 3.1.2).

The effects of oxidative stress depend on the cell type, the level of oxidative stress experienced, and the protective mechanisms in place in that cell type. For example, lymphocytes from the elderly appear to be more sensitive to exposure to hydrogen peroxide than those from young adults (Lopez-Hellin et al., 1998). In lymphocytes, iron is an effective catalyst in the induction of lipid peroxidation (Cardier et al., 1995;Carrasco-Marin et al., 1996;Lambert et al., 1996) whilst in isolated intestinal cells it has relatively little effect in vitro (Bhaskar and Balasubramanian, 1995;Lund et al., 1999;Srigitidhar and Nair, 1997). The sensitivity of cells to oxidative stress depends on their intrinsic antioxidant systems, in particular the levels of glutathione within the cell (Banki et al., 1996). As an example of this heterogeneity of response, the expression of heat shock proteins has been examined in response to exposure to hydrogen peroxide (Jackson et al. unpublished observations). In these studies, human lymphocytes were found to respond to hydrogen peroxide at 10-20 lmol=1, whereas skeletal muscle cells did not respond until approximately 10-fold higher peroxide concentrations (100-200 lmol=1).

Measurement of steady-state levels of highly reactive species always presents a problem as the rate of synthesis and degradation may be more important. It is now clear that peroxynitrite can be formed efficiently from NO Å and superoxide anions at physiological pH (Reiter et al., 2000). The steady-state concentrations of constitutively formed NO Å , whether free (almost immeasurable) and in its nitrosothiol forms (low nanomolar concentrations in blood), indicate the maximum peroxynirite that may be formed under specific conditions. Using peroxynitrite specific dyes in cell culture, values in the upper nanomolar range have been reported. However, these are not entirely quantitative methods. These values will increase considerably, for example, in inflammatory conditions when the production of NO Å and O ÅÀ 2 will be increased 100-fold in activated macrophages. Measurement of peroxynitrite products is more feasible, and has been determined in plasma as nitrotyrosine using differing techniques: these again indicated that low nanomolar concentrations seem to be typical (Frost et al., 2000;Khan et al., 1998).

div.head: Cellular responses to change in redox state
div.p: Total cell GSH levels may act as a signal transducer or modulator. When GSH levels are low the cell environment will be oxidising and the functioning of enzymes, particularly those with thiol groups, will be altered. As discussed above, this may have a particular impact on the activity of transcription factors. In some systems, hydrogen peroxide can actually act as a second messenger for various physiological agonists (e.g. angiotensin, inflammatory cytokines and growth factors (Bae et al., 1997)). In consequence, the background redox state of the cell will modify the specific responses. Haemoproteins may also act as redox detectors and signal transducer (Jungermann and Kietzmann, 1997). These act as both electron sinks and electron donors and, as such, are well placed to monitor the level of oxygen tension within the cell. It has also been proposed that lipid peroxides such as 4-HNE (4-hydroxynonenal) may act as signalling molecules within the cell leading to changes in cell proliferation or induction of apoptosis depending on dose (Ruef et al., 2001).

Most cells are poised in an unstable equilibrium between apoptosis and mitosis, and relatively mild, physiological/nutritional variations in redox state may be able to tip the balance in one direction or the other. Alternatively, oxidative stress directed toward immune cells may affect the functioning of that cell with the response dependent on the effectiveness of the intracellular antioxidant system. Some cells appear to rely on having a marginal level of protection to allow signalling to occur (Hehner et al., 2000). The effects of reactive oxygen intermediates and cell redox state are discussed below in respect of cell proliferation, apoptosis, necrosis, and immune cell function.

div.head: Proliferation
div.p: The rate of cell division is dependent on a wide range of factors, such as having sufficient supply of energy and other substrates required for metabolism, and the presence of cell survival signals in the form of growth factors. Many believe that the default state of the cell is to become apoptotic, and only as a result of the presence of survival signals does the cell avoid its own death. A range of pathways, which may be affected by ROS, drive cell proliferation. As described above, both Ras and PKC can be activated by exposure to ROS (Liou et al., 2000), and in turn stimulate a range of transcription factors including c-Fos, c-Jun and c-Myc, either directly or via the MAP kinase pathway. The two domains of PKC respond differently to two different types of agents: oxidants selectively react with the regulatory domain, stimulate cellular PKC, and signal for tumour promotion and cell growth. In contrast, antioxidant chemopreventive agents react with the catalytic domain, inhibit cellular PKC activity, and thus interfere with the action of growth promoters (Gopalakrishna and Jaken, 2000). Although the gene products formed as a result of some of these transcription factors are generally considered to be mitogenic some may result in differentiation, and some in apoptosis. The control of the balance between the different end points is complex; for example, c-Myc expression is high both during mitosis and apoptosis, but in the absence of growth factors, or when expression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 is low, apoptosis results as a consequence of raised c-Myc expression, rather than mitosis. Oxidative stress at levels too low to cause apoptosis can, in certain cases, induce temporary growth arrest. Micromolar concentrations of hydrogen peroxide have been shown to induce slowing down of the cell cycle at the same time as de novo synthesis of at least 20 proteins (Wiese et al., 1995), and subtle depletion of GSH can induce block in G2/M in Saos-2 and T98G cells, both of which lack functional p53 protein (Russo et al., 1995). There is also evidence that GSH depletion may modulate the response of the cell to hormonal regulation. For example, downregulating the response to glucocorticoids in vitro (Esposito et al., 1995) and in vivo (Ashida et al., 1997). At similar levels of GSH reduction, no effects on insulin or glucagon response were detected in vivo.

The role of NO Å in the regulation of cell proliferation has received relatively little attention, however, NO Å may play a role in regulating smooth muscle cell proliferation in vascular disease (Sarkar and Webb, 1998).

div.head: Cell death
div.p: Free radicals are recognised to play a part in both the induction of apoptotic cell death and in necrosis. Studies on pancreatic cells (Dypbukt et al., 1994) using a range of concentrations of the readily absorbable pro-oxidant quinone, 2,3-dimethoxy-1,4napthoquinone (DMNQ) to induce oxidative stress show a clear dose dependency of the effects of oxidative stress on cells. At low doses, cells expressed increased c-Myc and PKC, and subsequently increased cell proliferation rate. At intermediate concentrations, c-Myc remained elevated but expression of repair enzymes and p-53 increased, and cell proliferation dropped suggesting that DNA damage had occurred and cells had stopped cycling whilst attempting to repair. At this stage, and with increasing doses of DMNQ, apoptosis was seen until the dose was so high that acute cell damage occurred and necrosis was detected. It would seem likely that at the point at which DNA damage occurred the antioxidant protective mechanisms of the cell were failing to deal with the stress exerted (see Fig. 5).

Histologically, apoptosis is associated with cell shrinkage, membrane blebbing, chromatin condensation and the formation of fragmented chromatin into apoptotic bodies, whilst necrosis is associated with cell swelling and cell lysis with loss of cell content into the surrounding tissue. The processes underlying the controlled removal of cells, via apoptosis, are energy-dependent and thus require ATP. In contrast, necrosis is a passive process with cell swelling reflecting loss of osmotic control via such molecules as Na/K ATPase. During inflammatory reactions, free radicalmediated signalling may modulate the expression of pro-apoptotic cell surface changes such as the upregulation of fas (Apo1) and its ligand (Baran et al., 2001;Bauer et al., 1998;Furuke et al., 1999), and the appearance of phosphatidylserine on the outer cell membrane (Sambrano and Steinberg, 1995). These markers signal for the cell to be removed by neighbouring macrophages and other phagocytic cells. Alternatively, an excessive inflammatory response may lead to the release of high levels of hydrogen peroxide, through respiratory burst activity, and then lead to cell swelling and cell lysis with further release of cytolytic compounds leading to widespread necrotic cell death (Hirsch et al., 1997).

Intracellular glutathione concentration appears to play an important part in the induction of apoptosis, but the exact role is unclear (Hall, 1999;Hampton et al., 1998). In some systems, prevention of glutathione efflux appears to prevent apoptosis (Chiba et al., 1996;Ho et al., 1997a) whilst other groups see glutathione efflux as a bystander event in cell death (Jones et al., 1995). Secondly, the artificial lowering of cellular glutathione pools does not seem to induce apoptosis, and may indeed prevent apoptosis and possibly encourage necrosis in some systems (Sugimoto et al., 1996;Teramoto et al., 1999) whilst in others GSH removal has been reported to sensitise cells and increase apoptosis (Anderson et al., 1999;Boggs et al., 1998;Celli et al., 1998;Higuchi and Matsukawa, 1999;Si et al., 1998).

There exist two major pathways for the induction of apoptosis. In both, the redox state of the cell plays an important effector or regulatory role. A well-recognised reason for the induction of apoptosis is seen as a response to DNA damage, including oxidative damage. Detection of DNA damage is mediated through p53, and in the absence of wild-type p53 there is a significantly higher risk of clonal expansion of damaged cells, with the potential to form carcinomas. The mechanism by which p53 detects damage and signals the induction of apoptosis is not fully elucidated, but the mitochondria are involved.

Mitochondria integrate death signals through Bcl-2 family members, and coordinate caspase activation through the release of cytochrome c as a result of the outer mitochondrial membrane permeabilisation. Once in the cytosol, cytochrome c bind to Apaf-1 (apoptotic protease-activating factor 1) and, in the presence of ATP or dATP, this complex recruits and activates procaspase 9. Activated caspase 9 can, in turn, activate other caspases that are in charge of the cell's execution [see (Desagher and Martinou, 2000;Green, 2000) for reviews].

Mitochondria play a critical role in apoptosis induction in response to a wide variety of stimuli. Bax, a member of the Bcl-2 family, which is incorporated into the mitochondrial outer membrane and stimulates the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria, mediates signalling. The cellular response to a number of potentially anti-and pro-apoptotic stimuli is integrated, at the outer mitochondrial membrane. The mechanism leading to outer membrane permeability is not yet completely understood, but two prevailing theories have been postulated: (i) the non-specific rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane, as occurring after the activation of the so-called mitochondrial permeability transition pore (MPTP), and (ii) the formation of cytochrome-c-conducting channels (Desagher and Martinou, 2000;Green, 2000;Hengartner, 2000). In addition to cytochrome c, many other proteins normally confined to the intermembrane space of mitochondria are released during apoptosis. While the role of the majority of these proteins remains to be elucidated, some of them appear to be related to apoptosis. The formation of pores through which cytochrome c is released is believed to be controlled by the inclusion of different ratios of pro-and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family, Bax, Bad, Bim and Bid (Crompton, 1999;Voehringer, 1999).

The MPTP forms a channel between the inner mitochondrial matrix and the cytoplasm. The pores allow the movement of water and solutes, including calcium and cytochrome c, between the two compartments and not only have a role in controlling apoptosis but will also act as an arbitrator between apoptosis and necrosis (Hirsch et al., 1997). Other factors that impact on pore formation in the outer membrane include: (i) ceramide, which is released from the cell membrane in response to stress, (ii) free calcium concentration, which is sensitive to redox potential of the cell, and (iii) direct effects of endogenous free radical production (Green and Reed, 1998).

The release of cytochrome c activates caspase 9, a cysteine protease, which is cleaved proteolytically from its pro-form, which then activates caspase 3. Caspase 3 release signals to a number of pathways involved in the controlled dismantling of the cell, including cleavage of DNA into nucleosomes, changes in tissue architecture and upregulation of cell surface markers to indicate to neighbouring phagocytic cells that the cell should be removed (Sambrano and Steinberg, 1995). Members of the caspase family are cysteine-dependent enzymes and, as such, will be redox-sensitive (Kamata and Hirata, 1999). Recent work on hydrogen peroxide-mediated apoptosis suggests that prolonged or excessive oxidative stress can actually prevent caspase activation (Hampton et al., 1998), and thus may direct the cell more toward necrosis, presumably due to a complete loss in mitochondrial membrane potential and the consequent drop in ATP levels within the cell.

Smac/DIABLO, a second mitochondria-derived activator of caspases, promotes caspase activation in the cytochrome c (cyto-c)/Apaf-1/caspase-9 pathway. When released from mitochondria to cytosol, Smac binds to XIAP (chromosome X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis) thus removing its inhibitory effect on caspase-9 (Du et al., 2000). HtrA2, a recently identified mitochondrial serine protease, appears to operate similarly (Suzuki et al., 2001).

Although much attention has been addressed to the role of caspases in cell death, recent data indicate that, in many instances, mammalian cell death may be caspaseindependent. AIF (Apoptosis-inducing factor), a flavoprotein with a significant homology to plant ascorbate reductases as well as bacterial NADH oxidases, and normally confined to the mitochondrial intermembrane space, translocates to the nucleus, upon apoptosis induction, causing chromatin condensation and large-scale DNA fragmentation (Susin et al., 1996). Like cytochrome c, AIF is a phylogenetically old, bifunctional protein with an electron acceptor/donor (oxidoreductase) function, and a second apoptogenic function. In contrast to cytochrome c, however, AIF acts in a caspase-independent fashion. This alternative pathway provides redundancy that ensures effective execution of the cell death programme.

Increase in expression of p53 can signal to the cell to slow down cell cycling, usually by blocking in G1, prior to synthesis, and allow DNA repair or it may signal for the cell to enter apoptosis. Whether the cell tries to repair DNA or enter apoptotic cell death is dependent on a number of factors including the amount of Bcl-2, or related proteins (Bcl-x, Bcl-w intrinsically expressed in the mitochondrial membrane), the level of activation of poly ADP ribose polymerase (PARP) or c-myc expression (Garcia-Bermejo et al., 1998). The redox state of the cell may also alter the balance between death and repair, by affecting both the expression of relevant genes and the activity of enzymes at different redox potentials. Cells that lack functional p53 can still be induced to enter apoptosis by exposure to pro-oxidant stimuli (O'Connor and Lu, 2000;Vitale et al., 2000). In this situation, oxidative stress may provide a beneficial signal to cells by tipping the balance from mitosis to apoptosis, and thus engineering the removal of potential pre-neoplastic cells. For example, the polyunsaturated fatty acid, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) induces apoptosis in a redox-dependent manner in the p53 null colorectal cancer cell line HT29, which is associated with a protective effect of fish oil in vivo (Latham et al., 2001;Latham et al., 1999). This effect is associated with an increase in caspase 8 and caspase 3 induction in vitro and can be inhibited by specific caspase inhibitors.

The involvement of caspase 8 in the induction of apoptosis by EPA in p53-deficient cells expressing non-functional p53 suggests that EPA induces apoptosis by modulation of the second major signalling pathway, namely the death-receptor pathway. This pathway involves the binding of ligands to the CD95 receptor (fas, Apo1, TNF), causing clustering of the receptor and formation of a death-inducing signalling complex (FADD) (Yeh et al., 1998). Binding of pro-caspase 8 to the complex leads to cleavage and release of caspase 8 into the cytoplasm. Caspase 8 activates caspase 3, and may also act directly on other apoptotic substrates. The fact that the effects of EPA could be blocked by antioxidants suggests that the response involves changes in the redox state of the cell, or an increase in vulnerability of the cell to oxidation resulting from inclusion of EPA into the cell membrane. Thus, redox potential appears to modulate apoptosis through both the cell death pathway and via the cytochrome c pathway (Fadeel et al., 1998;Hampton et al., 1998;Liu et al., 2000;Wang et al., 2000). However, the two pathways do not operate entirely independently. In some cell lines, the presence of caspase 8 has been shown to activate Bid, a member of the Bcl-2 family, which is then incorporated into the mitochondrial membrane and increases the release of cytochrome-c and thus caspase 9 expression (Desagher and Martinou, 2000). The mitochondria not only respond to ROS but also release ROS in response to a number of pro-apoptotic stimuli. For example, tissue growth factor TGF-b, for hepatocytes, and interferon IFN-c mediate their pro-apoptotic effects via release of ROS, and the cellular response to the ROS can be blocked by increased expression of glutathione within the cell (Herrera et al., 2001a;Pierce et al., 2000). In the case of TGF-b it has been shown that this release of ROS precedes a reduction in Bcl-2 transcription, which itself precedes loss of mitochondrial membrane potential (Dw m ), cytochrome c release and caspase activation (Herrera et al., 2001b). In other cell types TGF-b can block the pro-oxidant effects of IFN, IFN-c by an upregulation of Bcl-x (Lee et al., 1999b). Yet increased oxidative stress has been associated with upregulation of Bcl-2 mRNA in glomerula cells (Sandau and Brune, 2000). These studies highlight another potential route by which ROS may be involved in the induction of apoptosis; that is via transcriptional regulation.

As described earlier many transcription factors have been shown to be involved in apoptosis, and are known to be modified by the redox state of the cell (Arner and Holmgren, 2000). However, these effects tend to be cell-specific, with apoptosis being associated with both an increase (Tiegs et al., 1998) and with a decrease in NFjB (Lallemand et al., 2001). No clearly delineated mechanism whereby ROS might modulate transcription of Bcl-2 family members has as yet been published, although it has been shown that increased DNA binding of NFjB is associated with a downregulation of Bcl-2 expression (Maldonado et al., 1997).

Whilst most of the literature associated with free radical modulaton of apoptosis focuses on superoxide and hydroxyl radical effects, NO Å is also recognised to play a role in the control of apoptosis. This topic has recently been reviewed by Chung et al. (2001). NO Å may be either pro-or anti-apoptotic depending on dose, duration and cell type. In general, long-term exposure to NO Å leads to an increase in apoptosis while a short, or low level, exposure can protect against the effects of trophic factor withdrawal. Induction of apoptosis involves activation of caspases, through cytochrome c release, whilst protection is associated with increased expression of Bcl-2 and direct inhibition of caspases by nitrosylation of the cysteine thiol group.

div.head: Immune cell function
div.p: As discussed above (Section 2.3.1) oxygen-derived free radicals play an important part in the mediation of inflammatory responses. Phagocytosis by macrophages and neutrophils leads to the rapid uptake of oxygen into the cell and the release of hypochlorous acid and hydroxyl radicals. Granulocytes release these compounds into the extracellular space leading to a less controlled induction of cell death in the surrounding tissue, with the potential to create necrotic rather than apoptotic cell death. Not only do immune cells produce ROS but they are also sensitive to external ROS due to their high polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) content. These cells are also atypical, compared with normal somatic cells, in that they contain high levels of antioxidant vitamins, presumably providing protection against the intrinsic risk posed by the high PUFA content (Knight, 2000). It may be that these characteristics provide a particularly effective method for sensing redox state and signalling within the cell, allowing control of the expression of cell adhesion molecules and the release of cytokines.

There have been remarkably few studies published specifically on the topic of oxidative stress and immune cell function. In a few cases the effects of specific nutrients have been put down to their pro-or anti-oxidant nature, but the evidence for this being the mechanism is often based purely on surmise. There is an extensive literature on the anti-inflammatory effects of n-3 PUFAs compared with n-6 PUFAs with similar numbers of double bonds (Harbige, 1998). These data would suggest that anti-inflammatory effects are associated with eicosanoid metabolism, rather than oxidative stress (Pietsch et al., 1995). However, consumption of n-3 PUFAs has been shown to be linked to increases in anti-oxidant enzyme systems, in particular glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and SOD concomitant with decreased expression of IL-1, IL-6 and TNF-a (Chandrasekar and Fernandes, 1994).

Volunteers fed fish-oil capsules have a decreased expression of many cell surface molecules on blood monocytes associated with antigen presentation (Hughes et al., 1996), which is likely to result in a reduction in the cell-mediated immune response typical of many inflammatory diseases. Consistent with this being a pro-oxidant effect, Hughes et al. have shown an increase in monocyte cell adhesion molecules in response to the antioxidant, b-carotene, at dietary achievable doses (15 mg per day, four weeks) (Hughes et al., 1997). b-Carotene has also been shown to counteract the reduction in delayed-type hypersensitivity induced seen in response to UV radiation (Sokol et al., 1993;Tang and Udey, 1991) and reduce the risk of skin cancer (Greenwald and Greenwald, 1983). The effects of b-carotene on immune cell function have been reviewed by Hughes (Hughes, 1999).

The interplay between signalling pathways associated with eicosanoids, such as prostaglandins and leucotrienes, and that by direct oxidative stress creates a very complex system when considering the effects of the PUFA. For example, n-3 fatty acids are more effective in reducing inflammation than are n-6 fatty acids (Miura et al., 1998), yet n-6 fatty acids favour the production of prostaglandin (PG)-E 2 over PGE 3 ; the former being effective in inhibiting the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1, IL-2 and TNF-a during cell-mediated immunity. However, these effects of PGE 2 occur only at high concentrations, and generally the eicosanoid metabolites of n-3 fatty acids are less inflammatory than those from n-6 fatty acids.

The importance of NF-jb in the initiation of many diseases has been reviewed (Chen et al., 1999). Rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, psoriasis and inflammatory bowel disease all result in the production of cytokines and perpetration of the inflammatory process (Brennan et al., 1995) involving NF-jb, and so modulation of the redox environment of the cell would be likely to benefit these conditions. These disease states have been reported to be associated with reduced glutathione stores within the cell. Addition of antioxidants is therefore likely to be protective.

Release of cytokines from the macrophage will aid the recruitment of T-helper cells, which in turn increase the immune response by further recruitment of T and B cells. Reduction in cell surface receptors for a particular cytokine will have the effect of reducing the immune response associated with that cytokine. The complexity of both the intracellular and extracellular signalling pathways means that it is extremely difficult to anticipate the overall response of a whole tissue to any factor up-or downregulating NF-jb expression or translocation to the nucleus. Simplistically, one would expect PUFA to increase oxidative stress, increase NF-jb and increase expression of cell adhesion molecules, but as described above this is clearly not the case for the n-3 fatty acids. Excessive immune suppression is likely to favour carcinogenesis. Increased cell proliferation, can arise in response to high levels of cytokines, which may also promote cancer. The complexity of the system requires considerably more understanding before over-simplistic dietary advice is given.

div.head: Reactive oxygen and nitrogen species -good or bad?
div.p: The traditional view of ROS is that they have a negative effect on cell function and viability, and therefore that substances that inhibit their reactivity (i.e. antioxidants) must be beneficial to cells. The increasing recognition of roles of ROS in cell signalling and modulation of gene expression has forced a re-evaluation of this simplistic view.

At the current stage in our understanding, it is not possible to provide a simple answer to the question: ''Reactive Oxygen Species -Good or Bad?''. Brief examples of two key cellular processes illustrate the dilemma:

div.head: Reactive oxygen species and cell death
div.p: Necrotic cell death following ischaemic reperfusion injury to tissue is undoubtedly deleterious to cellular function. The acknowledged role of ROS places them firmly in the 'bad' category. In contrast, the role that ROS play in apoptotic cell death (Section 3.1.2) can be seen as either 'good' or 'bad', depending on the particular cell system and process under study. Apoptosis of unrequired cells during development is undoubtedly beneficial to the organism, whereas inappropriate apoptotic cell death in some inflammatory disorders is likely to be deleterious.

div.head: Reactive oxygen species and inflammation
div.p: The multiple roles of ROS in inflammation are also potentially seen as 'good' or 'bad'. The overt pro-inflammatory role of these substances is clearly seen as beneficial in providing an improved immune response following infection, but deleterious in propagating an inappropriate inflammatory response in disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis (Winrow et al., 1993).

It is apparent that our understanding of the roles of ROS and antioxidants must be based on improved knowledge of their actions in specific physiological and pathophysiological processes. The impact of this is that a general statement, concerning the role of additional antioxidants in this area, is premature given the lack of knowledge concerning their ability to interfere with the redox-regulated processes described here together with vagaries of their bioavailablity (see Chapter 2: Bioavailability and Metabolism) and lack of specificity of biomarkers (see Chapter 3: Biomarkers).

div.head: Are specific reactive oxygen species and antioxidants involved in modulating cellular responses?
div.p: ROS and RNS may directly, or indirectly, trigger the expression of redox-sensitive genes in the organism (Sen, 2000). Changes in the cellular redox state, represented, for example, by the ratio of oxidised to reduced thiols, have an impact on the regulation of gene expression (Sen, 2000). Such changes allow the organism to respond to oxidative stress caused by altered cellular, or environmental, conditions. Oxidant signalling and the redox state are influenced by the antioxidant defence systems, including low molecular weight dietary antioxidants, both classical and 'indirect' and endogenous compounds such as glutathione.

If individual pathways are influenced by specific ROS then it is possible that the roles of antioxidants may also be specific. Most experimental work in this area has used powerful reducing agents (glutathione, N-acetyl cysteine, etc.) to demonstrate an effect on experimental systems and clear evidence for an effect of dietary antioxidants is sparse (Sen et al., 2000;Sen and Packer, 1996).

Cellular redox homeostasis is likely to be influenced by a number of different environmental and dietary factors, in addition to 'classical' antioxidant compounds. Thus, cellular redox is traditionally assumed to be dictated by the major cell thiols (glutathione, etc.), which are dependent upon an adequate supply of reduced nucleotides (NADH, NADPH, etc.). From a general cell regulation point of view, the key determinants of these are adequate supplies of cellular energy, the rate of energy consumption, exposure to environmental oxidising agents, etc. Thus, it can be seen that while dietary antioxidants may be important, the overall energy intake and expenditure, thiol amino acids or environmental oxidising agents may also act to influence redox-mediated cell signalling and responses. Future work in this area should examine the effects of antioxidants within the framework of regulation of cell thiol homeostasis, rather than in isolation.

div.head: Specific effects of dietary antioxidants in cell regulation
div.p: There is increasing evidence that some of the dietary antioxidants exhibit biological activities that are not directly related to their antioxidant proper-ties. It has been suggested that they influence signalling processes and regulation of gene expression, via pathways independent of antioxidant functions. The term 'dietary antioxidants' comprises a variety of structurally very different compounds.

In Bioavailability and Metabolism (Chapter 2) of antioxidants, several examples of the biological potency of metabolites have been mentioned. One of the most impressive examples is the function of the b-carotene metabolites, all-trans and 9cis-retinoic acids, which are ligands of nuclear receptors (Chambon, 1996). They regulate RAR and RXR, which are transcription factors that interact with retinoic acid-responsive elements in the promoter region of retinoic acid-sensitive genes. Here, we describe effects of parent antioxidants on gene expression and regulatory pathways in the cell. It should be noted, however, that in most cases little is known about the underlying biochemical mechanisms.

div.head: Carotenoids
div.p: In context with the suggested cancer-preventive activities of carotenoids, their stimulatory effects on gap junctional communication are discussed as a property that is clearly not related to antioxidant activities. For gap junctional communication, cell-to-cell channels provide a direct pathway for the diffusion of small molecules (<1000 Da) between the cytoplasm of adjacent cells (Donaldson et al., 1997). It has been postulated that intercellular communication, via gap junctions, plays a role in the regulation of tumour cell growth. Retinoids and carotenoids (Bertram and Bortkiewicz, 1995) stimulate this communication pathway. The stimulatory effects of carotenoids are not limited to pro-vitamin A compounds. In addition to a-and bcarotene, lycopene and some xanthophylls are active. The mechanism of activation is not yet understood. In vitro, it has been shown that the expression of connexin is increased upon carotenoid treatment. For retinoids, post-transcriptional effects on the stability of mRNA have been suggested to be involved. For some carotenoids metabolites may play a role in the pathway of activating gap junctional communication.

Several animal studies in rats have shown that some carotenoids are capable of inducing xenobiotic metabolising enzymes, including P 450 -dependent enzymes, pnitro-phenol-UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (4NP-UGT) or quinone reductase (QR) (Astorg et al., 1994;Gradelet et al., 1996a,b). These enzymes play a pivotal role in the detoxification of exogenous compounds including drugs and toxins. Canthaxanthin and astaxanthin are inducers of cytochromes CYP1A1 and CYP1A2. Similar effects were observed with b-apo-8 0 -carotenal. In contrast, b-carotene, lutein and lycopene had no influence. b-Carotene, astaxanthin, canthaxanthin and b-apo-8 0 -carotenal effects on CYP1A1 were also investigated in mice (Astorg et al., 1997). In this species, only canthaxanthin exhibited a weak effect. The other carotenoids did not stimulate CYP1A1 activity. Again the mechanisms underlying the induction are not known.

In a study from the US, it has been shown that the CYP1A2 activity in human populations correlates with plasma levels of micronutrients (Le Marchand et al., 1997). Based on the data, it was suggested that about a third of the variation in enzyme activity is related to diet. Plasma carotenoid levels were negatively associated with CYP1A2 activity, with lutein exhibiting the most pronounced effect. Lycopene was the only carotenoid investigated in this study that was positively correlated to enzyme activity.

Studies in vitro have demonstrated that carotenoids, especially lycopene which has an exceptionally high activity, inhibit the growth of mammary, endometrial and lung cancer cells (Levy et al., 1995). Cell treatment was associated with diminished insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-1 receptor signalling, activation of the transcription factor AP-1, and effects on cell cycle progression. It was suggested that the effects on cell growth are related to carotenoid-mediated interferences with signalling pathways that might be independent of antioxidant activities (Karas et al., 2000). It is not yet clear if the parent carotenoids, or metabolites, exert these biological activities. Interestingly, cooperative effects between lycopene and vitamin D have been related to inhibitory effects on cell cycle progression and differentiation in cell culture (Amir et al., 1999).

div.head: Vitamin E
div.p: The anti-atherosclerotic activities of a-tocopherol have been related to its chainbreaking properties preventing lipid peroxidation and formation of atherogenic oxidised LDL (Sies et al., 1992;Traber and Sies, 1996). There is increasing evidence that a-tocopherol also affects other pathological pathways in the development of atherosclerotic lesions including the proliferation of smooth muscle cells, monocyte adhesion, thrombocyte aggregation and neutrophil activation (Azzi et al., 2001;Azzi and Stocker, 2000). The inhibitory effects of a-tocopherol on PKC may make an impact on these processes. The inhibition is specific for the PKC isoform PKC-a, and mediated indirectly by the prevention of a phosphorylation step that activates the enzyme. Other vitamers with comparable antioxidant potential like b-tocopherol are not active, which strongly suggests that the mechanism of inhibition is independent from pro-oxidant-antioxidant pathways. There is evidence that a-tocopherol is involved in the control of tocopherol transfer protein synthesis, collagenase expression and regulation of scavenger receptor activity (Azzi et al., 2001). Again b-tocopherol does not exhibit such activities.

It is important to highlight the fact that a-tocopherol is only one form out of the eight naturally occurring forms of vitamin E. The antioxidant functions of the seven other forms are also starting to be appreciated. Thus, it has been shown that glutamate-mediated cytotoxicity, towards the neuronal cell line HT4, can be efficiently inhibited by a-tocotrienol at far lower concentrations than those needed for protection by a-tocopherol (Sen et al., 2000). It has also been suggested that the ring structure of c-tocopherol favours scavenging of RNS more than ROS, and may complement a-tocopherol in its antioxidant function (Christen et al., 1997). Additionally, various forms of vitamin E have effects on cell signalling systems that have yet to be explained.
