Tocotrienols have a cholesterol lowering effect in animal models, probably by their inhibitory effects on 3-hydroxy-3 methyl-glutaryl, (HMG) CoA reductase (Qureshi et al., 2001). Also, c-tocopherol has been shown to inhibit cyclooxygenase activity (Jiang et al., 2000) and interfere with apolipoprotein B (ApoB) synthesis in cells in culture (Theriault et al., 1999). Whether these activities relate to their antioxidant activities remains to be demonstrated.

div.head: Flavonoids
div.p: Flavonoids show various biological effects other than antioxidant effects. Among these are inhibitory effects on PKC and PI-3K (Gamet-Payrastre et al., 1999). Plant flavonoids attenuate inflammation and immune responses, possibly via inhibitory effects on regulatory enzymes linked to the biosynthesis of prostaglandins, which represent a group of pro-inflammatory signals (Manthey, 2000). One of the most interesting compounds in this group is the isoflavone genistein found in high amounts in soybean products (Barnes et al., 2000;Kurzer and Xu, 1997). The phytoestrogens exert their effects on estrogen-dependent cells binding preferentially to the b-estrogen receptor. Isoflavones have also been shown to inhibit protein tyrosine kinases.

Citrus flavonoids have been shown to exhibit a number of anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer actions in vitro and in vivo, likely due to their interactions with key regulatory enzymes involved in cell activation and receptor binding. In vivo, citrus flavonoids may induce hepatic phase I and II enzymes, and citrus flavonoid metabolites have also shown biological activity (Manthey et al., 2001). Furthermore, some pharmacological activities of flavonoids might be related to the inhibition of metallopeptidases responsible for the splitting of regulatory neuropeptides (Bormann and Melzig, 2000).

Various flavonoids have been used as tools for inhibition of several important enzymes. Thus, the isoflavonoid genistein and the flavonoid quercetin have been used to inhibit protein kinases. Less recognised is the activity of these substances on the DNA structure modulatory enzyme topoisomerase type II (Skibola and Smith, 2000). Inhibition of this enzyme in actively proliferating cells increases the frequency of DNA translocations (Strick et al., 2000). Such translocations are frequently observed in cancer cells and are believed to be important in the development of the malignant phenotype of the cell. It has been suggested that excess dietary flavonoids may increase the probability of giving birth to children with a congenital type of leukaemia, namely myeloid lymphoid or mixed lineage leukaemia (Ross, 2000). Cell culture experiments with flavonoids have indeed shown that, for example, quercetin induces reciprocal translocation of DNA between chromosome 9 and 11 or 4 and 6 (Strick et al., 2000).

div.head: Inducers of phase II enzymes
div.p: The antioxidant potential of phase II enzyme induction has been reviewed and compounds involved in these processes described as indirect antioxidants (Fahey and Talalay, 1999). There are at least nine distinct chemical classes of phase II enzyme inducers, exerting a wide range of potencies. They are all chemically reactive with sulphhydryl groups, and cause oxidation, reduction, or alkylation. Unlike direct antioxidants, phase II enzyme inducers are not able to participate in radical or redox reactions as such (Dinkova-Kostova et al., 2001;Plumb et al., 1996). Thus, they cannot act as pro-oxidants, and they are not consumed stoichiometrically when acting as indirect antioxidants. Some of the classes of inducers are toxic at low doses, but most of the dietary compounds identified show no toxicity at dietary levels. Phase II enzymes, such as glutathione transferases (GSTs), NAD(P)H: QR and haem oxygenase, also play a central role in xenobiotic metabolism in addition to metabolising a broad spectrum of ROS. It is likely that the ability of the induced enzymes to detoxify reactive electrophiles can explain the major mechanisms of the antioxidant potential of phase II enzyme inducers (Fahey and Talalay, 1999).

Some GSTs, especially of the alpha class, have selenium-independent, glutathione peroxidase activity on organic (hydro)peroxides. GSTs prevent lipid peroxidation and DNA damage by reducing DNA base hydroperoxides and lipid hydroperoxides (Ketterer et al., 1987). GSTs also conjugate lipid peroxidation products, such as propenal, which reacts with DNA and thereby detoxify these potentially toxic products (Berhane et al., 1994). Oxidised (o-quinone) metabolites of neurotransmitter catecholamines are also substrates for GSTs. These cause redox cycling toxicity that is diminished after conjugation with GSH (Segura-Aguilar et al., 1997). QR possesses antioxidant activity in cells by catalysing the two-electron reduction of quinones and thereby detoxifies exogenous quinones (Prochaska and Talalay, 1991). Furthermore, it reduces coenzyme Q, an endogenous quinone, and thus plays an important role in the protection of lipid membranes against oxidative stress (Beyer et al., 1996). QR has also been shown to reduce a-tocopherolquinone resulting in the formation of its hydroquinone, and maintaining cellular antioxidant function (Siegel et al., 1997). A combined activation of both QR and GST by multi-targeting phase II enzyme inducers in neuronal cells has shown to reduce the toxicity of dopamine, and therefore may lead to a protective potential against certain neurodegenerative diseases (Duffy et al., 1998;Murphy et al., 1991). Haem oxygenases are another group of enzymes induced by phase II enzyme inducers. This enzyme exerts its antioxidant activity by catalysing the conversion of haem to biliverdin, which is then reduced to the antioxidant bilirubin (Stocker et al., 1987). Inducers of phase II enzymes may also elevate tissue GSH by raising the activity of c-glutamylcysteine synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme of GSH synthesis. As for GSTs, QR and haem oxygenase, the induction is mediated via the ARE in the 5 0 -upstream region of the gene (Mulcahy et al., 1997). Since phase II enzyme induction lasts for a relatively long period of time (approximately days), they exert ongoing and prolonged antioxidant activity, and thus high cellular concentration need not be maintained continuously.

div.head: Disease states affected
div.p: The wide spectrum of cell signalling and transcriptional processes influenced by the redox state of the cell implies that ROS are likely to be involved directly, or indirectly, in the pathophysiology of a number of disorders. Most interest has concerned cancers, where the involvement of ROS as regulators of cell proliferation and apoptosis is clearly important. Several intervention studies have addressed whether supplemental antioxidants can influence the incidence of specific cancers with variably disappointing results (see Table 3 in Chapter 1), but interventions designed to target specific redox-regulated processes have not been undertaken.

In the area of coronary heart disease ROS have long been implicated in the oxidation of LDL as a key step in the pathophysiology of artheromatous plaque formation (Esterbauer et al., 1993). Various intervention studies to address the possibility that antioxidants might reduce this oxidation have been undertaken, again with variably disappointing results (see Table 2 in Chapter 1). The recognition of regulatory roles of ROS in cell proliferation suggest that the oxidative processes occurring in the vessel wall -in early coronary heart disease -may play additional roles in other aspects of the disorder such as the characteristic proliferation of vascular cells. Again, intervention studies to address these possibilities have not been undertaken.

While most interest has concentrated on cancers and coronary heart diseases, ROS are implicated in many of the chronic ageing-related disorders such as diabetes, degenerative neurological disorders including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, autoimmune disorders including rheumatoid arthritis, eye disorders including macular degeneration and age-related loss of musculoskeletal function. Modifications of redoxregulated cellular processes may play a role in all of these conditions, but firm data for many are lacking.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Oxidative phosphorylation occurs in the mitochondria of cells and the generation of ATP, by this process, appears to be the principal function of these organelles (Fig. 6). The mitochondrial system of oxidative phosphorylation consists of five protein complexes. Complexes I and II collect electrons from NADH and succinate, respectively, and pass them to ubiquinone, which is oxidised by ubiquinone cytochrome c oxidoreductase (complex III) and cytochrome c oxidase (complex IV) (Papa and Lorusso, 1984;Saraste, 1999;Wallace, 1999). With the exception of complex II, each of these complexes couples electron flow to proton pumping (Papa et al., 1999a,b;Papa and Lorusso, 1984;Saraste, 1999;Wallace, 1999) and the ensuing protonmotive force is utilised by complex V (F 0 F 1 H þ ATP synthase) to form ATP from ADP and P i (Boyer, 1997;Papa et al., 1999a,b).

ROS production by the respiratory chain can be prevented by mild uncoupling effected by free fatty acids (Korshunov et al., 1998), thyroid hormones (Papa and Skulachev, 1997), and specific proteins like the uncoupler protein (Ricquier and Bouillaud, 1997). Uncoupling of respiration prevents ROS production by decreasing the concentration of oxygen and auto-oxidisable one-electron reductants in complexes I, II and III. The same effects can be produced by factors causing slips in redox proton pumps like the respiratory Dw m , high rates of delivery of reducing equivalents to the respiratory chain, and possible ligands (Papa et al., 1999a,b;Papa and Skulachev, 1997).

When the food calorie intake does not exceed a normal overall energy demand, the aerobic oxidation of respiratory substrates -derived from nutritional components -is essentially utilised to produce ATP with minor production of NADPH and negligible production of ROS (Fig. 6). The efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation is adjusted to around 40% by the competition between the promotive ATP synthase on one hand, and leakage in respiratory proton pumps (Boyer, 1997;, proton back flow by free polyunsaturated fatty acids (Korshunov et al., 1998), and specific proton-conducting proteins like the uncoupler protein, particularly active in certain tissues (Ricquier and Bouillaud, 1997), and hormone-regulated decoupling, on the other (Papa and Skulachev, 1997). Thus the diet can play a significant role in the modulation of ROS production.

div.head: Mitochondrial generation of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species
div.p: The respiratory chain is responsible for most of the ROS produced in human tissues (Chance et al., 1979). Mitochondrial respiration accounts for about 90% of cellular oxygen uptake, and 1-2% of the oxygen consumed is converted to ROS (Chance et al., 1979). In mitochondria, oxygen superoxide ðO ÅÀ 2 Þ is generated by complexes, I, II and III of the respiratory chain, but not by cytochrome c oxidase, which seems to display SOD activity (Markossian et al., 1978;Papa, 1996) (Figs. 6 and 7). When the supply of respiratory substrates, derived from food, exceeds the ATP demand production of NADPH, which supports fatty acid and cholesterol syntheses, and of ROS is promoted. Under these conditions, the phosphate potential ([ATP]/[ADP]½P i ) is high, aerobic Dw m in mitochondria depresses respiration (State 4), the electronegativity of auto-oxidisable redox carriers in complexes I, II and III and cellular oxygen tension rises with consequent enhanced ROS production (Cadenas et al., 1992;Chance et al., 1979).

The auto-oxidisable redox intermediates in complex I and II are flavin radicals, non-haem iron and semi-quinone radicals, the latter two species are also present in complex III (Cadenas et al., 1992;Cross and Jones, 1991;Papa, 1996). The level of these reactive reductants, and hence of ROS, can be enhanced by defects in respiratory complexes or by inhibitors of complex III (e.g. antimycin) (Azzi et al., 1974;Kostantinov et al., 1981), or of complex I (e.g. rotenone) (Turrens and Boveris, 1980), or neurotoxic meperidine analogue derivatives 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3, 6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) and 1-methyl-4-phenyl pyridinium cation (MPP þ ) (Cleeter et al., 1992;Cortopassi and Wang, 1995;Hasegawa et al., 1990) [see however (Singer et al., 1995)], which cause Parkinsonism-like symptoms (Langston et al., 1983). O ÅÀ 2 produced at the cytosolic surface of the inner mitochondrial membrane can be oxidised by cytochrome c, and cytochrome-c oxidase or converted to insert hydrogen peroxide, by the cytosolic Cu, Zn-SOD. O ÅÀ 2 produced at the matrix side is essentially converted to hydrogen peroxide by the Mn-SOD of the matrix (Fridovich, 1995). Inactivation of MnSOD in transgenic mice has been found to enhance ROS level, and to result in lethal dilated cardiomyopathy, with inactivation of mitochondrial enzymes containing iron-sulphur centres (Bironaite et al., 1991). A particularly deleterious situation seems to arise in patients with inherited disorders of complex I. Defects in the assembly or activity of the complex result in enhanced ROS production. This induces over-expression of the mitochondrial MnSOD, which increases production of hydrogen peroxide (Raha and Robinson, 2000).

Superoxide can react with NO Å , produced by cytosolic NOS or directly by the mitochondrial isozyme (Tatoyan and Giulivi, 1998), with formation of the peroxynitrite anion ðONOO À Þ. NO Å can reversibly inhibit cytochrome c oxidase (Brown, 1999) and ONOO À can oxidatively damage respiratory complexes with further production of O ÅÀ 2 , thus setting in a deleterious cascade of events (Beckman and Koppenol, 1996). In both the matrix and cytosol hydrogen peroxide is reduced to water by glutathione peroxidase (Chance et al., 1979). Hydrogen peroxide, which diffuses to peroxisomes, is cleaved there by catalase to water and oxygen (Chance et al., 1979). The excess hydrogen peroxide can be converted to Å OH if copper or iron ions are present (Chance et al., 1979).

div.head: Mitochondria and apoptosis
div.p: The role of ROS and RNS in apoptosis has been partially discussed in Section 3.2.2.

div.head: Mitochondria and antioxidant defences
div.p: Whilst mitochondria are a major cellular site for production of ROS and are themselves a first target of oxidative damage, these organelles are equipped with various antioxidant defences. A list of mitochondrial antioxidant defences is presented in Table 2. GSH and GPx represent the most important antioxidant systems in mitochondria. Mitochondrial reduced glutathione (GSH) plays a key role in the protection against the oxidative damage to mitochondrial components. Indeed, the oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA that occurs upon ageing is directly related to an oxidation of mitochondrial GSH. GSH oxidation increases with age in mitochondria from liver, kidney and brain of rats (Vijg, 1999). These results support the idea that mitochondria are a major source of free radicals in ageing (Felkai et al., 1999;Raha and Robinson, 2000;Sohal and Weindruch, 1996;von Zglinicki et al., 2000) and emphasise the relevance of mitochondria as primary targets of damage associated with ageing (Sohal and Weindruch, 1996).

A change in the GSH : GSSG redox status would indicate that mitochondrial antioxidant systems cannot cope with the oxidant species generated throughout the cell life. GSH oxidation may be an early event in the chronic oxidative stress associated with mitochondrial ageing. This points out the importance of maintaining an adequate GSH status to protect cells against oxidative damage.

At present, the precise role of ubiquinone (or CoQ) in mitochondrial ageing is still controversial. It is considered an antioxidant, or free-radical scavenger, in membranes (Migliaccio et al., 1999). In addition, CoQ preserves cellular integrity and function since it supports ATP biosynthesis in the mitochondrial inner membrane (Lanza et al., 2000). A slow decrease of CoQ levels in some organs, particularly in the heart and thymus, upon ageing has been reported (Lanza et al., 2000;Michikawa et al., 1999). The therapeutic effects of CoQ have been attributed to its antioxidant properties, which prevent losses of mitochondrial bioenergetic function caused by oxidative stress (Papa, 1996). On the other hand, it is well known that mitochondrial peroxide production is linearly related to the amount of ubiquinone present (Papa et al., 1996). Furthermore, reduced ubisemiquinone (Q À ) would be involved in the formation of Å OH, even in the absence of the iron and copper complexes (Gadaleta et al., 1999).

Defence, mediated by antioxidant enzymes, in mitochondria involves MnSOD and GPx. By using purified synaptic mitochondria, some authors have found a marked decrease in MnSOD activity in the brain cortex upon ageing, whereas it increases in non-synaptic mitochondria with age (Lenaz, 1998).

div.head: Key role of mitochondrial GSH in the defence against oxidative damage
div.p: The usual levels of mitochondrial GSH, and some of its properties have been described (Jocelyn, 1975). The fact that GSH content in mitochondria is different, and is regulated in different ways, to that of cytosol, implies that GSH should be considered as two separate pools (Wahllander et al., 1979).

The origin and turnover of mitochondrial GSH have been studied (Griffith and Meister, 1985). There is no synthesis of GSH in mitochondria. Rather, GSH is imported from the cytosol (Griffith and Meister, 1985). The mitochondrial GSH carrier was cloned and expressed in 1995 (Garcia-Ruiz et al., 1995).

Depletion of mitochondrial GSH is important in several diseases. Damage to muscle mitochondria occurs after depletion of GSH (Martensson and Meister, 1989). Such a damage is prevented by GSH monoethyl ester, which repletes mitochondrial GSH levels. Furthermore, an impaired uptake of GSH by hepa-tic mitochondria occurs in chronic ethanol-fed rats (Fernandez-Checa et al., 1991).

The role of mitochondria in ageing attributed to free radical damage of mitochondrial function was first described in 1980 (Miquel et al., 1980). They pointed out that mitochondria are important sources of free radicals in ageing, and that mitochondrial components are essential targets of free radical damage, which occurs upon ageing (Miquel et al., 1980). Changes of total cellular GSH upon ageing are only modest. The differences that can be observed are about 10-40% (Viñ na et al., 1992). However, changes in mitochondrial GSH are much more marked. Oxidised GSH levels in mitochondria from the brain of old animals have been observed to be at least four times higher than those from young animals (de la Asuncion et al., 1996). Furthermore, changes in the redox state of GSH in mitochondria correlate with changes in oxidative damage of mitochondrial DNA. Treatment with dietary antioxidants prevents the oxidation of mitochondrial GSH associated with ageing (de la Asuncion et al., 1996). Furthermore, late onset administration of dietary antioxidants, such as thiol-containing compounds or vitamins C and E, prevents oxidation of GSH, oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA, and the loss of motor co-ordination associated with ageing (Pallardo et al., 1998).

Apoptosis causes the release of GSH from the mitochondria and its subsequent oxidation. This correlates with oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA (Esteve et al., 1999). Thus, the GSH redox status may be important in controlling critical functions for mitochondrial and cell survival such as the opening of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore.

div.head: Mitochondrial oxidative damage
div.p: Oxidative modifications of mitochondrial proteins increase with ageing (Ames et al., 1993). Oxidation of mitochondrial protein by ROS has been found to affect the F 0 F 1 ATP synthase (Guerrieri et al., 1993), respiratory enzymes (Forsmark-Andree et al., 1997), the adenine nucleotide carrier (Forsmark-Andree et al., 1995), and to open the MPTP (Griffiths and Halestrap, 1995).

With age, the fluidity of cell membranes, including the mitochondrial membrane, decreases and this is associated with enhanced lipid peroxidation (Laganiere and Yu, 1993); the linolenic acid content of mitochondrial lipids, in particular of cardiolipin, decreases with increased PUFA, which are more sensitive to oxidation reactions (Laganiere and Yu, 1993). Cardiolipin oxidative damage is particularly deleterious as this phospholipid seems to be required for the activity of mitochondrial enzymes (Hoch, 1992;Paradies et al., 1997;Robinson et al., 1980) and metabolite translocators (Kramer and Palmieri, 1989). Membrane damage caused by lipid peroxidation can be repaired by phospholipase A 2 . This enzyme removes oxidised lipids from membranes (van den Berg et al., 1993), and its activity increases under conditions of oxidative stress (Hatch et al., 1993).

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is particularly susceptible to oxidation (Richter et al., 1988). ROS have been found to induce extensive mtDNA deletions in cultured fibroblasts (Yoneda et al., 1995). Deletions, point mutations and 8-oxo-dGua in mtDNA increase with in ageing and in age-related diseases (Gadaleta et al., 1999;Lenaz, 1998).

A human cell contains hundreds of mitochondria, each of which contains 5-10 mtDNA genomes (Wallace, 1999). This relative abundance of mtDNA copies implies that rearrangement and base substitution mutations in an mtgene in germline and/or somatic cells have to affect a substantial proportion of its copies, so as to result in a phenotypic decline of oxidative phosphorylation and, when more pronounced, in an overt pathological condition.

div.head: Direct oxidative damage to the mitochondrial electron transport chain
div.p: The components of the mitochondrial electron transport chain all display varying degrees of susceptibility to oxidising species. Oxidative stress is associated with a loss of mitochondrial function and suggest that complex IV (cytochrome oxidase) may be particularly vulnerable (Harley et al., 1993;Heales et al., 1995;Sokol et al., 1993). This susceptibility may arise in part from the dependence of this complex for cardiolipin (Soussi et al., 1990). Cardiolipin is required for maximal complex IV activity. Conditions that favour lipid peroxidation (e.g. vitamin E deficiency) are associated with a loss of complex IV activity (Thomas et al., 1993). Furthermore, Trolox â , a water-soluble vitamin E analogue, protects complex IV from oxidative damage (Heales et al., 1994).

Complex I (NADH ubiquinone reductase) activity is also reported to be depressed in some models of oxidative stress. However, within the brain, the sensitivity of this complex appears to be related to GSH availability. Thus, oxidative damage (e.g. by RNS) only occurs in the presence of a marked GSH deficiency (Barker et al., 1996). This finding may have relevance for our understanding of Parkinson's disease -i.e. in this condition loss of GSH and complex I activity has been reported in the substantia nigra of Parkinson's disease patients (Jenner et al., 1992;Schapira et al., 1990).

Oxidative stress is implicated as an important factor in the neurodegenerative process and there is evidence of mitochondrial damage at the level of the electron transport chain (Heales et al., 1999).

div.head: Nitric oxide and damage to mitochondria
div.p: Activated macrophages develop an NO Å -mediated inhibition of DNA synthesis, the Krebs cycle enzymes aconitase and malate, and succinate-dependent cellular oxygen consumption (Drapier and Hibbs, 1988). This implies inhibition at the level of complexes I and II of the mitochondrial respiratory chain. In addition to NO Å ; ONOO À also appears to inhibit overall cellular respiration (Szabo and Salzman, 1995) in macrophages. Similar mechanisms seem to be responsible for NO Åmediated macrophage killing of tumour cells (Amber et al., 1991;Stuehr and Nathan, 1989).

In hepatocytes, citrate-, malate-and succinate-dependent oxygen consumption were inhibited by a NO Å -mediated mechanism. (Phillips et al., 1996;Stadler et al., 1991). In isolated liver mitochondria, ascorbate plus tetramethylphenylenediamine, an artificial substrate for complex IV-mediated oxygen consumption, are also inhibited by a similar mechanism (Schweizer and Richter, 1994).

Within the central nervous system, iNOS induction in astrocytes is accompanied by the selective and irreversible inhibition of complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain (Bolanos et al., 1994). This effect is prevented by the inhibition of NOS activity with the L -arginine analogue Nmonomethyl-L-arginine, suggesting that the biosynthesis of NO Å is a necessity for the effect on complex IV. Moreover, incubation with LPS/IFN À supplemented with SOD plus catalase (CAT) prevents such complex IV damage, suggesting the involvement of endogenous formation of superoxide anion (O ÅÀ 2 ). Inducible nitric oxide syntase (iNOS) activity synthesises O ÅÀ 2 as well as NO Å (Xia et al., 1998) and, therefore, peroxynitrite anion can be endogenously formed by the direct reaction of Å NO with O ÅÀ 2 (Beckman et al., 1990). It can be concluded that the irreversible complex IV damage after iNOS induction in astrocytes seems to be due to ONOO À rather than to NO Å itself (Bolanos et al., 1997).

Despite irreversible complex IV damage by the endogenous ONOO À formation in astrocytes, simultaneous measurement of NO Å and oxygen concentrations in activated astrocytes has shown a reversible effect of NO Å on oxygen consumption (Brown et al., 1995). This reversible inhibition of oxygen consumption is possibly due to the competition of endogenously formed NO Å with O 2 for complex IV, as previously reported in synaptosomes using NO Å (Brown and Cooper, 1994). In addition, irreversible inhibition of oxygen consumption has also been observed. In the presence of the NOS inhibitor N(G)-mono-methyl-L-arginine (L-NMMA), the rate of O 2 consumption was restored to only 73% in the rate of O 2 consumption in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)/IFN-c treated astrocytes when compared with controls (Brown et al., 1995). Experiments using purified complex IV have demonstrated that its activity is directly, and irreversibly, inhibited by ONOO- (Sharpe and Cooper, 1998), confirming the results in the intact astrocytes (Bolanos et al., 1994). Endogenously formed NO Å also causes transient inhibition of ATP synthesis in cultured primary neurons (Almeida and Bolanos, 2001), supporting a role of NO Å in the regulation of the mitochondrial function within the central nervous system.
Nothing is known about the effects of the role that dietary components may play in these processes.

div.head: Effects of nutrients on mitochondria
div.p: This section will consider a number of examples of nutrient effects on oxidant generation and activity in mitochondria. Surprisingly, most work in this area has considered caloric restriction rather than antioxidant effects.

div.head: Caloric restriction and antioxidants
div.p: Caloric restriction (CR) extends the maximum life span (MLS) of animals (Masoro, 2000;Sohal and Weindruch, 1996). Experimental evidence for this effect has been obtained in rodents (Masoro, 2000;Sohal and Weindruch, 1996) as well as in primates (Ramsey et al., 2000). Demographic studies are directed to analyse the dietary regimens of subgroups of population with extended MLS (Koenig, 2001). Different hypotheses have been put forward to explain the effect. However, this is a complex condition the outcome of which depends on the interaction of a variety of genetic and stochastic factors. It was argued that the metabolic rate, in particular respiratory activity, is inversely correlated with MLS in animals (Sohal and Weindruch, 1996). It was, then, hypothesised that CR prolongs MLS by decreasing the metabolic (respiratory) rate (Sacher, 1977). Since respiration can generate ROS it was suggested that the life prolonging effect of CR was due to decreased production of ROS and amelioration of oxidative stress (Dubey et al., 1996;Matsuo et al., 1993;Sohal and Weindruch, 1996). Rodents show attenuation of cellular oxidative damage when subjected to CR (Sohal et al., 1994a;Sohal et al., 1994b). Other mechanisms, like modulation of insulin production and control of glycemia (Masoro, 1996), improved response to low intensity stress (Masoro, 2000) and changes in the gene expression profile (Kayo et al., 2001) in response to CR, have been proposed. Nevertheless, prevention of oxidative stress by CR remains the most attractive hypothesis.

Recent studies from Weindruch and colleagues using DNA microarray technology have addressed the mechanisms by which CR influences the ageing process. These data are entirely compatible with a role in modulation of oxidant generation and defences as (at least) part of the protective process (Lee et al., 1999a;Lee et al., 2000a,b). Since it is not a feasible public health strategy to reduce dramatically the caloric intake of the population, studying the role that the dietary antioxidants in reducing the rate of ageing could lead to an important understanding of how the quality of life in the elderly might be improved, especially if combined with an analysis of variations in the caloric contribution of the macronutrients. It is generally felt that in a balanced diet carbohydrate should contribute 70-75% of the caloric need. These requirements need to be evaluated in the context of the rate of ageing.

div.head: Lipids
div.p: Various lipids, including ceramide and particularly free fatty acids (FFA) influence mitochondria. Long chain FFA at micromolar concentration exert an uncoupling effect on oxidative phosphorylation due to their protonophoric activity (Korshunov et al., 1998). This uncoupling effect may have beneficial antioxidant effect as, by speeding up the mitochondrial respiratory activity, it prevents O ÅÀ 2 production, by lowering the oxygen concentration and the steady-state level of autoxidisable intermediates in complexes I, II and III (Table 2) (Papa and Skulachev, 1997). At higher concentration (10 À5 -10 À4 mol/l) unsaturated fatty acids (arachidonate) inhibit complexs I and III, and promote ROS production in these complexes. These effects, which are likely to be negligible in vivo under normal physiological conditions, where the concentration of FFA is kept low ð$10 À6 mol=lÞ may become relevant under various conditions including exhaustive exercise (Klug et al., 1984), ethanol abuse (Lange and Sobel, 1983;Laposata and Lange, 1986), cold stress (Brustovetsky et al., 1990) and tissue ischaemia (Takeuchi et al., 1991). At higher concentrations arachidonate causes, in the presence of calcium, release of cyto-chrome c from mitochondria and opening of the cyclosporin-sensitive PTP (Di Paola et al., 2000).

The mild uncoupling effect of FFA may prevent generation of ROS by mitochondria in the resting state (Korshunov et al., 1998). Following a given stimulus, such as TNF-a; which causes activation of cytosolic PLA 2 (Wissing et al., 1997), cellular concentration of arachidonic acid may rise substantially. Under these conditions, both a larger uncoupling and inhibition of respiratory enzymes occur. ROS will be now extensively produced (Cocco et al., 1999). This condition, which is typical of the post-ischaemic heart, is accompanied by opening of PTP and release of cytochrome c (Di Paola et al., 2000).

FFA have been described to cause either apoptosis, or necrosis, in living cells. In cultured cardiomiocytes, palmitate has been reported to cause both necrosis and apoptosis (Kong and Rabkin, 2000). Progression to necrotic, or apoptotic cell death, depends upon ATP level. In turn, this will be regulated by the extent of the uncoupling produced by FFA and by their effect on the membrane permeability (Lemasters et al., 1999).

div.head: Antioxidants
div.p: Experiments carried out on rats fed with a vitamin E-deficient diet have shown this to result in a neuromuscular syndrome associated with nonspecific degenerative changes in the mitochondrial structure, depressed respiratory activity, and a significant decrease of the activity of complexes I and IV (Thomas et al., 1993). The antioxidant vitamin E is present in the mitochondrial membrane (Thomas et al., 1989). A study of the effect of dietary fats on the mitochondrial content of vitamin E found that administering olive oil -as the only dietary fat -to rats resulted in a significant increase of vitamin E content in heart mitochondria compared with only dietary soya oil or butter.

The a-tocopheryl radical, produced in the reaction of tocopherol with ROS (Thomas et al., 1989), can be restored by the reduced form of ubiquinone in the inner mitochondrial membrane pool (Kagan et al., 1990). Reduced ubiquinone can also act directly as a quencher of oxygen and lipid peroxyl radicals (Ernster et al., 1992;Forsmark et al., 1991), although UQ can be reduced to UQ-semiquinone radical. There is abundant, but controversial literature on the in vivo antioxidant activity of quinones.

There are studies indicating that the red-wine polyphenol resveratrol exerts protective effect against lipid peroxidation (Zini et al., 1999). Furthermore, this compound scavenges O ÅÀ 2 produced in mitochondria and decreases the activity of complex III, by competing with ubiquinone (Zini et al., 1999). The polyphenol (3,4dihydroxyphenyl)-ethanol (present in olive oil) counteracts ROS toxicity but these experiments have been undertaken in cultured human cells (Manna et al., 1997).

div.head: Techniques and approaches
div.p: Elucidation of the manner in which ROS and antioxidants influence signalling pathways and gene expression in whole cells and mitochondria has primarily been undertaken by traditional biochemical and cell and molecular biological techniques. In most cases, this has involved assessment of effects on single pathways or small numbers of genes. The techniques involved have included assessment of mRNA abundance using northern or dot blotting or RT-PCR-based approaches and single protein abundances using antibody-based techniques. These methods are relatively time-consuming and cumbersome and hence it has not been possible for investigators to evaluate more than a few dozen pathways, or proteins, over a number of years. A number of new techniques have been developed, including non-invasive methods to study mitochondrial function, and array-based methods for assessment of mRNA abundance. It is now feasible for an investigator to assess the abundance of thousands of mRNA species simultaneously to permit evaluation of multiple potential pathways and patterns of gene expression (Weindruch et al., 2002). Rapid throughput methods exist for evaluation of protein content and composition (proteomics) and transgenic technologies enable the effect of upregulation or deletion of a single gene in whole organisms or a single tissue to be examined. This section of the review will outline these new technologies and how they may contribute to this area of research.

div.head: Mitochondrial techniques
div.p: Intact mitochondria are traditionally isolated following tissue homogenisation and centrifugation. For skeletal muscle, a trypsin digestion step is added, to facilitate breakdown the muscle fibres, and thus enable optimum homogenisation (Heales, 1999). From brain, it is possible to isolate two distinct populations of mitochondriai.e synaptic and non-synaptic mitochondria using high speed differential centrifugation and a Ficoll gradient system (Lai and Clark, 1979).

Mitochondria are suspended in an appropriate buffer system and functional integrity assessed, using a range of substrates and a Clark-type oxygen electrode (Heales, 1999). Rapid freezing of the sample and storage at )70°C allows for direct enzymatic analysis of mitochondrial enzymes and antioxidant status at a later date (Heales et al., 1995). Electron flux, via the electron transport chain, can also be assessed following the preparation of submitochondrial particles. These are prepared by sonication of isolated mitochondrial preparations. This results in an inversion of the inner mitochondrial membrane allowing direct access to the electron transport chain. However, these preparations are devoid of mitochondrial matrix enzymes and contain variable amounts of outer membrane (Ragan et al., 1987). Furthermore, submitochondiral particle preparations are also likely to be devoid of key mitochondrial antioxidants such as GSH.

It is important to note that, on some occasions, different mitochondrial preparations can yield different results. Thus, incubation of submitochondrial particles with the mitochondrial toxin, 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium, leads to increased oxygen radical formation, whereas the converse is true when intact brain mitochondrial preparations are used (Bates et al., 1994;Cleeter et al., 1992).

Each of the complexes of the respiratory chain exerts varying degrees of control over respiration, and substantial loss of activity of an individual respiratory chain complex may be required before ATP synthesis is compromised. Furthermore, within the brain, mitochondrial appear to be heterogeneous in nature and, depending on cell type, display different threshold effects: for example, complex I of synaptic mitochondrial has to be inhibited, in vitro, by approximately 70% before ATP synthesis is compromised whereas in synaptosomes the threshold is approximately 25% (Davey et al., 1997;Davey and Clark, 1996).

Assessment of mitochondrial bioenergentics by P-NMR in vivo is now widely used in elucudating potential functional defects in energy supply in patients with putative defects in mitochondrial metabolism. Measurements of N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) by NMR may be an indicator of brain mitochondrial function in vivo.

NAA is found at very high concentrations in the mammalian brain. Whilst the function of NAA is not known, it appears to be predominantly located in the neuronal cells (Clark, 1998). NAA is synthesised from aspartate and acetyl CoA in the mitochondrial matrix and is exported from the mitochondrion. Furthermore mitochondrial damage (e.g. arising as a result of oxidative stress) can lead to a loss of brain NAA in vivo (Heales et al., 1995). Magnetic resonance spectroscopy can detect brain N-acetyl compounds in vivo, and has been used in a clinical setting (Clark, 1998). As, NAA appears to be the predominant component of the N-acetyl signal, loss of this signal has been proposed to represent neuronal damage arising as a result of mitochondrial damage (Clark, 1998).

Recent advances in microscopy and imaging techniques have added further tools to the study of mitochondria within living cells. In particular, fluorescence imaging allows the study of mitochondrial physiology in single, living cells in real time, often in concert with other cellular activities such as calcium signalling or pH changes. Fluorescence technology has chiefly been used to measure: (i) mitochondrial membrane potential ðDw m ), (ii) mitochondrial calcium handing, and (iii) mitochondrial autofluorescence as an assay of redox state.

The mitochondrial membrane potential, Dw m lies at the heart of mitochondrial biology. It defines the transport of ions and (some) substrates, and of course provides the driving force for oxidative phosphorylation. By following the (re)distribution of fluorescent lipophilic cations, fluorescence technology is most often used to assay Dw m . Many fluorescent compounds, most notably rhodamine 123 (Rh123), tetramethyl rhodamine ethyl and methyl esters (TMRE and TMRM, respectively), are both cationic and membrane-permeant. They cross the cell membrane easily, and partition between cellular compartments in response to the standing electrochemical potential gradients. Thus, depolarisation of mitochondria induces a redistribution of the fluorescent probe, which can be followed and measured using digital imaging techniques. [For recent reviews see (Duchen et al., 2001;Mojet et al., 2001).]

Mitochondria participate in cellular calcium signalling. Esters of calcium-binding fluorescent dyes will load into mitochondria if they also carry a positive charge. Once loaded, mitochondrial esterases cleave the ester moiety leaving the calcium probe trapped within mitochondria. This technique has been used to follow mitochondrial participation in calcium waves, in glial cells (Boitier et al., 1999), cardiomyocytes (Trollinger et al., 1997) and hepatocytes (Byrne et al., 1999) amongst others. For a recent review, see (Duchen et al., 2001). As with Dw m -sensitive probes, calcium-sensitive fluorophores allow measurement of mitochondrial calcium changes in real time.

Intermediaries of the electron transport chain, NADH and FAD, are naturally fluorescent. The term autofluorescence is used to distinguish the fluorescence that arises from endogenous compounds intrinsic to the cell from that of exogenous probes as described above. NADH is fluorescent and NAD is not, while FAD fluoresces and FADH does not. Therefore, as electrons are passed from these reducing equivalents to the electron transport chain, their fluorescence can be followed and used as an assay of mitochondrial redox state.

div.head: cDNA microarray approaches
div.p: A large amount of sequence data from the human genome, and similar projects are either nearing completion or are completed for common laboratory animal species. To take full advantage of these developments, it will be necessary to evaluate rapidly the expression of a large number of genes. cDNA microarrays can be used to facilitate these analyses. Many laboratories and commercial facilities are now developing approaches to studying mRNA expression profiles, ranging from glassbased arrays of polynucleotides, where assessment of many thousands of sequences can be achieved, to less comprehensive nylon filters containing cDNA sequences for several hundred known genes. The opportunity to study the effect of oxidants, or antioxidants, on multiple mRNA abundances by comparisons of mRNA extracted from cell lines, or tissues of animals or humans, is therefore available, but there are no reports of their use in this area.

These approaches have been rapidly applied to investigate a wide variety of biological problems, such as the changes in genes expression that occur in specific disease states such as cancers (Kudoh et al., 2000;Ono et al., 2000). These studies have been further facilitated by the development of laser capture microdissection techniques to obtain specific cells from affected tissues as targets for the microarray analyses (Burgess and Hazelton, 2000). The approach has also been successfully used to evaluate functionally relevant signalling pathways (Harkin, 2000), and to identify genes responsive to the activation of common transcription factors (Guo et al., 2000). These rapid developments have also highlighted the need for improved information technology and data management with large amounts of newly available data, and such facilities have also developed rapidly (Liao et al., 2000;Shatkay et al., 2000;Sherlock et al., 2001).

Although many studies have reported single experiments using cDNA microarrays, the precision and accuracy of this approach has been questioned by some authors and protocols for statistical evaluation and replication of microarray analysis have been presented (Lee et al., 2000a,b).

The approach has been used to learn more about the effect of ageing and of factors influencing ageing processes on gene expression (Lee et al., 1999a;Lee et al., 2000a,b). These studies have helped to illustrate the involvement of oxidative stress in the ageing process and provide an indicator of the type of information that can be obtained with this burgeoning technology.

div.head: Proteomics approaches
div.p: This approach is currently less accessible to many researchers because of the cost and availability of appropriate mass spectrometry equipment. The proteome of a cell is defined as all of the proteins that are present in a cell at a particular time, reflecting those genes that are expressed at that time. Proteomics is aimed at identifying and quantifying those proteins. It is seen as a complementary technology to the cDNA microarray approach since it provides information on translated proteins and on their post-translational modifications. Although DNA chip-based gene expression screening is currently a favoured approach to monitor responses to dietary components the correlation between mRNA and protein expression is debatable. A correlation coefficient of 0.48 has been determined for expression levels in human liver measured by two-dimensional electrophoresis, (protein abundances) or transcript image analysis.

Furthermore, after translation many proteins are further processed e.g. glycosylation. Such modifications are not apparent from the genome, but are often critical for protein folding and function. Oxidation of proteins markedly alters their physicochemical properties e.g. the increased electrophoretic migration of LDL. Thus, post-synthetic modifications also represent a level at which proteomics can discern expression polymorphism. The direct determination of expressed protein polymorphisms provides an attractive alternative to mRNA analysis. Proteomics relies upon the application of several key technologies: two-dimensional gel electrophoresis to separate the cellular proteins, image analysis to analyse the complex patterns of proteins seen on the gels, mass spectrometry to identify the proteins extracted from the gel following proteolytic digestion, and sometimes sequence analysis for definitive identification (Trayhurn, 2000).

Two-dimensional (2D) separation of proteins has been widely applied, over many decades, to visualise proteins. However, the problems of reproducibility have precluded detailed analysis of protein levels. The use of IPG (immobilised protein gradient chips) strips and pre-cast gels, in association with 'flicker' software to allow overlaying of images, has made analysis much more robust. It is possible to resolve thousands of proteins on a 2D gel. With the increase in sensitivity for protein sequencing, it is now possible to isolate a spot, digest the protein with trypsin, and resolve the different fragments by gas spectrometry. However, the greatest leap forward is due to the many sequence databases available that enable identification of proteins based on peptide fragmentation pattern or mass spectrometry sequence analysis. Further developments have demonstrated the ability to western blot 2D gels for oxidised amino acid residues (manuscript in preparation; Grant and Griffiths), without the need for derivatisation prior to separation. Resolution of altered electrophoretic mobility, altered expression level, and post-synthetic oxidation of proteins are possible using this technique. Fig. 8 shows the effect of supplementation with ascorbic acid (400 mg per day) on protein carbonyl content and nitrotyrosine in plasma from a normal subject, where high molecular weight proteins show a greater evidence of protection by dietary antioxidants. These methodologies will allow for a greater analysis of micronutrients effects on patterns of expressed proteins both from specific cellular sources, and within plasma. This will provide information on the effects of dietary components on protein expression and, therefore, improve our understanding of the physiological roles of important micronutrients. This approach may be particularly applicable in research into the effects of ROS and antioxidants, where non-enzymatic modifications to proteins may be an important consequence of interaction between free radicals and proteins. 7.4. Transgenic mice as tools in antioxidant research 7.4.1. Gene knockout and over expression

Transgenic technology provides a powerful tool for investigating the interaction between antioxidants, oxidative stress and gene regulation in a complex mammalian system. One approach is to manipulate genes of interest, and subsequently study the effect of altered gene expression. For example, several models have been developed to elucidate the function of crucial endogenous antioxidant enzymes such as SOD, Fig. 8. D electrophoresis of plasma protein carbonyls and nitrotyrosines from a normal subject supplemented with ascorbic acid (400 mg/day) for 20 weeks (weeks 0-20).

GPx, catalase and thioredoxin. These models, which utilise knockout or gene overexpression methodologies, provide the opportunity to assess the relative importance of genes involved in antioxidant defence. The utility of these techniques can be seen in transgenic mice models with alterations in SOD expression. Knocking out the gene encoding the mitochondrial isoform (Mn-SOD) is lethal. Mice homozygous for this mutation die shortly after birth and exhibit severely damaged organs, particularly heart and brain (Lebovitz et al., 1996;Li et al., 1995).

Mitochondrial analysis shows that oxidative damage of several key proteins is evident (Melov et al., 1999). Interestingly, by treating the animals with an exogenous antioxidant such as the SOD-mimetic MnTBAP (Manganese 5, 10, 15, 20-tetrakis (4-benzoic acid) porphyrin), the mice are partly rescued. Life span is increased from eight to 16 days, and damage seen in some of the organs from untreated animals is absent or drastically reduced. In contrast to the Mn-SOD-knockout mice, mice that are deficient in cytosolic SOD (Cu/Zn SOD) or the extracellular SOD are apparently healthy and normal. However, when challenged with an oxidative insult by paraquat, mice, which lack Cu/Zn-SOD, show an increased susceptibility to the insult compared with their wild-type littermates (Ho et al., 1998).

Overexpression of the different SODs can result in striking differences. High expression of Cu/Zn-SOD leads to a phenotype resembling Down's syndrome, whereas overexpressing the Mn-SOD leads to normal and healthy mice with no major differences in antioxidant or oxidative status. Interestingly, in mice that overexpress Mn-SOD in pulmonary tissue (Wispe et al., 1992), or in heart (Yen et al., 1996), a greater protection is afforded against oxygen toxicity.

Genetically engineered mice, which lack the gene encoding glutathione peroxidase (GPx), show no apparent phenotypic changes under normal physiological conditions (Ho et al., 1997b). However, they display increased sensitivity to ischaemia/reperfusion in heart tissue (Maulik et al., 1999). On the other hand, mice that over express the same gene have protection against this and similar kinds of insults (Furling et al., 2000;Maulik et al., 1999). Similarly, transgenic mice over expressing thioredoxin or catalase show increased protection when challenged with oxidative stress. A better protection against streptozotocin or alloxan induced diabetes was observed if these genes are over expressed in pancreatic b-cells (Hotta et al., 1998;Xu et al., 1999).

Knockout mice for the redox-sensitive transcription factor Nrf2 have been produced. Nrf2 activates a number of genes encoding phase II enzymes or antioxidant enzymes including SOD, catalase and c-glutamylcysteine synthetase (the rate limiting enzyme in GSH-synthesis), which are modulated through antioxidant response elements (AREs) (Chan and Kan, 1999). When mice lacking Nrf2 were treated with the chemopreventive agent oltipraz, only wild type mice were protected against benzo[a]pyrene-mediated carcinogenesis, whereas Nrf2-deficient mice were not able to induce defence enzymes necessary to combat the carcinogenesis (Ramos-Gomez et al., 2001). In addition, SOD, catalase and c-glutamylcysteine synthetase, which all are regulated by Nrf2, have reduced activities in these mice (Chan and Kan, 1999).

Relevant transgenic models are also those that alter expression of genes to promote diseases where antioxidants and oxidants play a role. For example, transgenic mice, which overexpress an inhibitor of pRb in the choroid plexus in the brain, develop tumours spontaneously, but the degree varies with the intake of antioxidants (Salganik et al., 2000). Another relevant model is the amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) model in mice expressing a mutant Cu/Zn-SOD (G93A) (Gurney et al., 1994). This mutation leads to a 'gain of toxicity' and kills motoneurons, possibly because of increased oxidative stress. The mutation in Cu/Zn-SOD is common in ALS patients and the phenotype is reproduced in the ALS-mice. The usefulness of these animals in an antioxidant intervention experiment was recently demonstrated using the combined SOD/catalase mimetics EUK-134 or EUK-8. ALS-transgenic mice survived longer than non-treated mice (Jung et al., 2001).

A mutant mouse deficient in p66 shc , a protein important for relaying signals for growth, repair and apoptosis results in a 30% increase of lifespan. The mutation renders cells from the mouse resistance to the oxidative damage imposed by oxidative stress (Migliaccio et al., 1999).

All these models have demonstrated a role for antioxidants and antioxidant enzymes in the protection against oxidative stress, and the models have been instrumental in elucidating this role. However, by their very nature, models can be blunt scientific instruments. Disrupting or changing the expression of a single gene may disrupt a coordinated and well-regulated network of enzymes, and can lead to imperceptible alterations in the animal's physiology. In addition, conventional knockout technology makes it impossible to study the effects of some of the gene deletions in adult or ageing mice, as many genes such as MnSOD are lethal at an early age.

The emergence of the powerful Cre-lox technology is promising because it allows conditional knockout of a specific gene both in a time-and tissue-specific manner. In such mice a modified edition of that gene replaces an endogenous target gene. The modification consists of the insertion of two loxP sites, which flank an exon in the gene targeted for inactivation. Cre recombinase is an enzyme that recognises the loxP sites leading to an excision of the exon thus rendering the gene non-functional. Cre expression can be directed to any organ under the control of tissue-specific promoters or inducible promoters induced by exogenously added ligands such as tetracycline (Furth et al., 1994;Saam and Gordon, 1999;Utomo et al., 1999). Expressed Cre can then, in theory, inactivate genes of interest in any desired organ at any time whether that is during development, in disease, during ageing or in dietary intervention studies.

div.head: Transgenic reporter mice
div.p: Cell experiments and experiments in animals have shown that dietary antioxidants influence gene regulation. For example, the activities of NF-jB and AP-1 seem to be enhanced by certain ROS and suppressed by various antioxidants (Sen and Packer, 1996), whereas Nrf2 may be activated directly by some dietary antioxidants (Dinkova-Kostova et al., 2001). The dietary regulation of these transcription factors may be studied using transgenic mice containing DNA-regulatory elements coupled to a reporter gene that does not exert any physiological effect and the animals are phenotypically normal.

The luciferase gene has been used as a reporter. It has a relatively short half-life making it suitable for assessment of dynamic changes in gene activity. It is also sensitive and easy to assess in tissue homogenates or cell extracts. Importantly, the signal derived from luciferase, and a few other reporter genes, can also be monitored non-invasively (Contag et al., 1998;Weissleder et al., 2000;Yang et al., 2000;Yu et al., 2000), which allows assessment of gene regulation in individual animals over a time course. This approach reduces the number of mice required and the variation between them. This technology still lacks the necessary resolution and depth to give detailed information on tissue expression. However, as a means of screening the effect of dietary constituents on certain transcription factors during ageing, disease or under normal physiological conditions, the technology can provide useful data. Indeed, Carlsen et al. have recently shown that NF-jB activity after treatment of animals with NF-jB modulators and in pathogenesis can be monitored non-invasively (Carlsen et al., 2002).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: • Reactive oxygen species play a key role in modulating changes in gene expression and cell function. • Reactive oxygen species act through the key signalling and response systems of cells. • Mitochondria are a major source of oxidants, and susceptible to oxidative damage. • Evidence indicates that oxidant-regulated changes in gene expression can be modified by a number of reducing agents, etc. but the relevance of these in vitro studies to potential nutrient effects on gene regulation in humans is unclear. • Some oxidant-regulated changes in gene expression are protective. It is not clear what the effect of ''antioxidants'' is on these or whether it is appropriate to attempt to manipulate them. • Changes in gene expression may be ''biomarkers'' of oxidant stress, but there is a need to understand further the implications of these changes. • There is evidence that some dietary substances can modify cellular redox, but further work is required to understand potential effects of diet on redox-related changes in gene expression. • Much of the data available in this area have been obtained from cell culture and animal experiments, but there is a need for more improved and sophisticated animal models to help understand mechanisms. These should include conditional knockout and transgenic mice and non-invasive reporter models for imaging gene expression.

div.head: Future research needs
div.p: • It is essential to identify tissue specific patterns of gene expression that are linked with disease states and modifed by dietary constituents.

• There is a need to understand the implications of a reduction in mitochondrial complex activity unrelated to changes in cellular ATP levels and effects of diet on this. • Development of a ''redox-regulated'' gene microarray chip would help tell us about the mechanisms of action of antioxidants and antioxidant mixtures. • Studies are required to determine whether DNA arrays can be used for risk/benefit analyses of nutrients in animal and humans at levels of nutrients relevant to dietary intakes. • More information is needed on the effect of genetic differences on the generation and responses to reactive oxygen species. • The relevance of studies involving transformed cancer cell lines and non-physiological oxygen tensions requires re-assessment.
